Here are a few tips if you are new to DE Shaving: get a good shaving brush because without a good lather on your face your more likely to irritate the skin and cut yourself, invest in a good DE Razor (since they last a very long time) and finally find the right soap that will provide a good lather on your face while also moisturizing it.

  3. A year later and the box is still nearly full.

  5. They provide a very close shave. Some of the people who use double edge safety razors claim they can only get 2 shaves out of a blade. I get 5 shaves out of one of these.<br /><br />I have very coarse hair and they cut it down with no problem. They work a lot better than the sample Merkur blade that came with my Merkur razor.
  6. They're good. Just get them. Nothing more to say.
  7. I purchased this lot of 100 blades nearly two years ago. I really think of these as more of a &#34;four and a half:, but I do not want to skew the blade's ranking. I would have used more than the fifteen blades (or so) in comparison to the thirty blades of Astra SS until I realized that my face seemed to prefer the SS's. I was quickly more tempted to use a SS, but did not experience trouble with the SPs, just less perfect shaves in comparison. I would suggest sampling each as neither are expensive for what one receives. The pillar packaging is cool for storage of other packs of blades as well, I nearly consider it a &#34;free&#34; bonus. I shave every day with cold water, for what its worth. Both of these Astras seem to be sufficient for shaving everyday without expecting trouble.
  8. For the price and the maker, I was at first skeptical but these razors are on par with the more expensive ones. Excellent price, and love the large quantity. I am set for years.
  9. My go to razor, I change them out every shave though.
  10. These are my current #1 blade choice after sampling about six different brands. I have used these in two different razors (a mild 1960's Gillette Tech and a contemporary Merkur 20C) and seen excellent results in both. Chances are you'll get similar results regardless of your razor choice. I am able to get at least 3 shaves from each blade, and the overall consistency from blade to blade is exceptional. There are a couple other blades I've tried that were just as comfortable and consistent, but the Astra SP price point is well below any competitor at the same level of quality.
  11. Best blades I've used. Have given several to some of my co-workers to try and they love them also. Definitely recommend them.
  12. After trying about 10 different brands and varieties of DE blades, these are my favorite. They shave my fairly coarse beard cleanly without pulling or irritation. I find these very slightly better than the Astra Superior Stainless blades. At this rate, I will spend less than 5 cents a week for blades.

  14. I really like these blades, they are sharp and get the job done. I use them in my EJ DE89LBl and get 3 shaves with 3 passes per shave. Will buy again.

  16. Blades are really tricky, especially double edge. I actually bought a sample pack that included 10 different brands of blade and out of the 10 - Astra was the best for me. I have thick coarse hair on my face and these blades performed better than the Feather blades I bought. I don't get any razor burn and I can use a blade 2-3 times before getting a new one. In fact, given how cheap these blades are - you could use a new one each time.
  17. Excellent blades for the price. I usually like feather blades but for the cost these are a great value considering how well they perform. Only get an occasional cruddy blade that is either duller or had a rough spot who nicks you.

  20. Very smooth blades love them
  21. Well I guess I'm just having a blast. I tested the sharpness level of and reviewed Feather double edge razor blades last week and then turned around and ordered Dorcos, Derbies, Sharks, Personnas and Gillette Silver Blues. I already had Astras and Wilkinson Swords on hand so didn't need to order them again. I tested again with the same edge sharpness instrument that I had used to test the Feathers. The company that sells the sharpness tester (my instrument is the one designed to test straight edge razors) says that they are going to make additional test media available on Amazon and I may need it if I keep this up. I could describe the test procedure I used and make this review long and drawn out but won't bore you with the details. In a nut shell ; while there appears to be some very small differences between these various brands in initial sharpness levels there isn't enough to write about. This is as opposed to the Feathers that tested a full 40% sharper. Please don't shoot the messenger! I am not a Feather salesman. In fact, the somewhat anecdotal preliminary tests I have conducted indicate that the superior edge on a Feather goes away very rapidly and much more rapidly than that of the less expensive brands but don't chisel that in stone just yet. Please keep in mind also that I tested only one product of each brand so it is possible that other models within the same brand might be sharper (or duller). If I come up with a good edge durability test I may be back because I'm just having to much fun with all this testing.
  22. TL;DR — These are my go-to blades for great, close shaves at an unbeatable price.<br /><br />Here is my review of the blades I've tried. There are a lot of sampler packs on Amazon, but after doing some research I chose to order around 30 each of just a few different blades to try, avoiding all of the lesser-quality &#34;filler&#34;. I'll compare here and there to Mach-3 blades since that's what I previously used before switching to electric, and now this.<br /><br />First off, Derby is what came with my razor. These you can practically rake across your face any way you see fit. They aren't very sharp, on par with a Mach-3 that's been used a few times. Shaving requires more strokes which leads to more irritation, especially on the neck. That said, I'd say these are a good blade if you're super worried about cutting yourself, because it's practically impossible. But even beginners might want to look elsewhere as these blades kind of ruin the &#34;shaving experience&#34;. Don't be disappointed if you just bought this razor and have only tried these blades! Keep reading...<br /><br />I ordered a 100-pack of Astra SP Platinum (that's Astra Superior Premium Platinum, not the regular stainless) since it's under ten bucks at the time of this writing. These are great. Beginners, start here. They're sharp enough that you don't have to press the razor against your skin—which you shouldn't have to! You're supposed to let the weight of your razor do the work as you guide it along your face in short strokes. So naturally, these are sharper than Mach-3 blades, but if you do press a little, you probably won't nick yourself. I love these blades because for me, they're comfortable enough for everyday use and provide good, close shaves at a very inexpensive price. Easy on my neck with care. My go-to blade. Great for beginners and pros alike, and eligible for Subscribe & Save!<br /><br />Wilkinson Sword Classic seem to be great blades for people who have their technique down prettywell. Compared to Astra SP Platinum, they are sharper. They provided the best shave of the lot, but I did nick myself here and there on my neck and below my chin the first time around. Do not push these blades against your skin. It doesn't take much mastery to use these, and they're worth working up to. Downside: more than twice the price of Astra SP Platinum. I'll keep some of these around for days when I want the closest shave possible, or I just feel like something different. If you're new to traditional shaving or think Mach-3 blades are sharp, maybe don't start here, but definitely try them out.<br /><br />Feather &#34;New Hi Stainless&#34; Platinum Coated blades are exactly what the reviews say: sharp. My first shave I got a good amount of nicks, but my second I had almost none. I adapted well, and you have to; each brand is a little different and the best require good technique, but some are more forgiving than others. These are negligibly sharper than the Wilkinson Sword Classic but they aren't forgiving at all and I didn't achieve any better of a shave. They're incredibly sharp compared to a Mach-3 blade. At 2x the price of the aforementioned and more than 3x the price of Astra SP Platinum, I won't be keeping these on hand, but your mileage may vary. If you only want the sharpest blade around, this is it. Fun fact: these come ten to a pack instead of five.<br /><br />In conclusion, I'm sticking with Astra SP Platinum for regular use and Wilkinson Sword Classic when I'm up for something sharper. I shave every other day, and either is priced reasonably enough that if I want, I can use each side of a blade just once for a fresh edge every shave. That's about a 100-pack every year, so do the maths on price. Of course, both brands last much longer than this if you're looking for even better value.

  41. these blades are a fantastic deal. they work nicely. only complaint is the large wax spots they use to adhere the blade to the paper. i prefer less wax on my blades.
  42. I have a very stiff beard and need really sharp blades, these don't do the trick. They work OK the first time but then not after that.   43. So many blades for such a low price. I use one blade a week with daily shaving. They're good quality blades.
  44. Paired these with my [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]] and my whiskers are a thing of the past. It seriously doesn't feel like I'm shaving, they're so smooth. Of course, every man's face is different so what works for me might not work for you so I would suggest buying less than 100 blades until you find yours but this brand is definitely worth a shot. The price to performance ratio is absolutely outstanding.<br /><br />As for the glue on the blades controversy; please don't worry. It's not glue, it's a light wax. It's there so the blades won't move around in their packages and potentially dull the edge. It doesn't affect the shave whatsoever and I don't even bother scraping it off. About three seconds under hot water and it's gone anyway (I soak my razor in hot water for longer than three seconds before I shave!) so don't worry about it!<br /><br />My only gripe is there's no little slot on the packages to put old razors in that a lot of other blade manufacturers use. You have to do the ol' wrap in toilet paper and into the trash routine to dispose of the blades. Not a big deal but I would prefer my used blades to be safely tucked away in a little cardboard container before I put them into the trash. Oh well, small trade off for a blade that works as well as this.
  45. I've tried a ton of different DE blades - Astra, Derby, various Personna, tons of different Gillettes, Treet, Wilkinson, Merkur, Bic, Feather, and I'm almost certainly forgetting others. Astra wins in my book as far as a budget blade is concerned. My top blades are the Gillette Silver Blue and the Personna Medical Prep, but the Astras are not far behind, and they are considerably cheaper. My razor is a Tradere OC, and with certain blades, one side will break before the blade dulls. This is certainly related to multiple factors, but if you've experienced this with other blades, know that the Astras probably will as well. This translates to running through blades more quickly (which ultimately means cost is increased) but again, heavily dependent on razor, etc. I shave a lot of my body, and I use my razor to trim other bits, and as far as getting a smooth shave and keeping nicks down, I would definitely recommend these for the price and availability. If you can spring for a bit more money, and aren't as worried about convenience, better choices can likely be had from shaving shops.
  46. Exactly what I wanted! Great blades, great price!
  47. These are the best safety razor blades I have used. I sampled quite a few in a 100 pack sampler as well. I'll never purchase another brand. Great price and a great shave.
  48. OK, yes, the little drops of goo on the blade from the wax wrapping is annoying, but it takes like seven seconds to remove with rubbing alcohol. Suck it up. For the price and quality of the blade (once it's clean), I haven't found a better value. I won't be buying blades for a couple years.
  49. I'm new to the Double Edge razor scene. After shaving with Gillette Fusion since I began shaving, I wanted to try something new. After seeing the Merkur 180 razor on a review of Father's Day presents, I decided on buying one for myself. Along with it, I bought these blades. First thing, these blades are insanely cheap. 100 for $10 is a price that can't be beat. I change the blade every other shave, but I don't worry about running out of blades any time soon.<br /><br />When I read reviews, people say that when using a Double Edge razor, they get the closest shave they ever had, compared to other high-priced razor cartridges. I believe it all depends on the blade really, and for me, these blades don't do the trick. Compared to a Gillette Fusion blade, there is a noticeable difference. You can see and feel the difference. (Sometimes after shaving with this blade, I redo my shave with a Fusion blade). I don't know if it's my technique, face structure, or the blade, but I just can't seem to get as close as I prefer.<br /><br />In conclusion, if you have yet to experience this blade, give it a shot. It's cheap so It's not like you're throwing your money away.
  50. These are simply the best of the brands of razor blades I've used over the years. They offer an ideal combination of sharpness and smoothness that beats all others! And the price is a steal, so don't hesitate!

If you wish for a more assertive blade, Feather is the ultimate, but they cut me terribly. The Astra blade will usually last me three shaves before beginning to dull. The price is right also.
  67. These are among the best razors I've used. I've tried Merkur, Shark, and other brands, and I find myself reaching for these every time I want a good shave. The individual packs inside the box are cardboard, and each blade is wrapped in a waxy paper. It should seal the moisture out well enough, but it may be a concern to some buyers. The blades themselves are fantastic, and very sharp. I've used them for 2-3 shaves before. If you're not sure which blades to get (there are so many brands out there), I would recommend going with Astra. I will be buying this brand again as my #1 choice in the future.

  100. After trying a [[ASIN:B003OL2LHC 24 FEATHER BLUEBIRD DERBY GILLETTE ASTRA TREET Blades Sampler]], I found these Astras to be the right balance for daily use (for me). I ordered this 100-pack and am generally satisfied with it, but as mentioned in another review, the blades are incompletely wrapped in wax paper and dabs of glue are used to make up the difference. The glue is often right on the edge of the blade, making the blade stick to the razor when trying to remove after use - a potential safety risk. I haven't noticed any difference in performance, but it seems the glue would collect shaving gunk and make it harder to rinse off... all of this could be avoided if they'd just wrap the blades properly and not use glue.<br /><br />Still, these are my daily blades and they work well enough for the price. They're sharp enough for a close shave, but not so sharp I have to be wide awake and extra-careful to avoid cuts. I use Feather blades if I haven't shaved for a few days, but for daily use these Astras are fine.<br /><br />Note: the other Astras were NOT as good for me, only Astra Superior Premium Platinum.<br /><br />My list of Amazon-acquired shaving gear:<br />[[ASIN:B003BHCAGQ Deluxe Stainless Steel Safety Razor and Shaving Brush Stand from Super Safety Razors]]<br />[[ASIN:B000S5PV56 Merkur Classic Barbor Pole Long Handle Safety Razor #38 + 10 Free DE Razor Blades]]<br />[[ASIN:B000F5NRQY Truefitt & Hill Ultimate Comfort Pre-Shave Oil, 2 oz.]]<br />[[ASIN:B000RG8D6K Truefitt & Hill 1805 Aftershave Balm]]<br />[[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]]<br />[[ASIN:B00020UQQQ Truefitt & Hill 1805 Shave Cream Jar]]<br />[[ASIN:B004COMB5W Osma Styptic Pencil, Hemo Stop]]<br />[[ASIN:B001G5HZCY Feather Hi-Stainless Platinum Double Edge Razor Blades 30 Ct]]<br />[[ASIN:B001QY8QXM 100 Astra Superior Premium Platinum Double Edge Razor Blades]]

  104. These were the first blades I've ever purchased and I'm so happy I went with this brand. Each blade will last around 3-5 shaves. Depending on the thickness of your hair and how sharp you need the blades to be. On a scale of 1-5 for sharpness, I'd give these a solid 4. If you're new to wet shaving, they wont tear your face up. If you're old friends with your smart razor, you can shave pretty fast with these blades and not worry about cutting yourself. I definitely get more brave after the 3rd shave I've gone through with the same blade. I'm sure you could use them more than 5 times, but at this price, just throw on a new blade and stop being cheap. For roughly 10 cents a blade, you cant beat that deal. It better than your Mock 3, Quatro, or 5 blade system you've used in the past. Just remember, this is 1 blade and you may have to take multiple passes. That 1 blade will be less stress on your face because you wont be running 5 consecutive blades across your face over and over. Give it some time, you'll learn to love it and never look back. If you liked my review, check out my reviews on other shaving products.

  111. I had originally bought 5 different brands of Double Edge razor blades from a shaving store on the West Coast to see which ones I liked best. Of the 5 I picked out which included Feather, Lord (platinum and stainless), Dorco, Derby , and the Astra. The Feathers were the sharpest and the next ones I liked were the Lords and the Astra. I decided to go with the Astra's because of the cost. These blades I got from Amazon just did not seem like the ones I got from the shaving store. Very inconsistent from one blade to another. Another reviewer who also gave this a one star said he thinks these are not true Astra's. He mentioned that the true Astra's are individually wrapped with paper saying Astra while these which he also mentioned are in plain white paper. I cannot verify this since I have used all my original Astra blades from the shaving store to see if the paper did have Astra written on the paper surrounding the blade. Another theory I had was that Astra was owned by Gillette and made in Russia. Proctor and Gamble bought Gillette and I have wondered if they have cut down on the quality. Again just a theory on my part, but I felt the quality on the Trac 3 blades went down in quality after the P & G purchase of Gillette which made me change to using double edge blades. I do not know if the original purchase from the shaving store was pre P & G.<br /><br />These blades were just not the same as my original Astra blades. I am finally down to my last 20 blades and looking to purchase another 100 blades and it will definitely not be these blades. In fact I am thinking I will buy them from a shaving store just to be safe.

  133. As someone my age, 27, who just started DE Shaving a few months ago these are the best blades I have found for myself. I have mildly sensitive skin, and besides using natural soaps, I have found that these blades when used correctly with the right soap don't irritate my skin at all. DE shaving takes practice like anything else but I get a closer shave then using the overpriced cartridge razors. Here are a few tips if you are new to DE Shaving: get a good shaving brush because without a good lather on your face your more likely to irritate the skin and cut yourself, invest in a good DE Razor (since they last a very long time) and finally find the right soap that will provide a good lather on your face while also moisturizing it.

  149. I purchased a few sampler packs when I began shaving with dual edge safety razors last year. These Astra blades were by far my favorite. I'll occasionally dip into my remaining sampler packs to see if my improved technique will affect their shave; these remain my favorite. Smoothness: 8 - I haven't tried a feather blade yet. Every review I've read indicates they'd beat the Astra. These are the smoothest I've actually used. My skin is fairly sensitive and I get razor burn easily. My Gillette Fatboy (settings 1-9, 9 being most aggressive) ranged between 1 and 4 depending on the razor. It's set to 3 for these and I can do two passes (1 with grain, 1 across) without any burn or bumps. Sharpness: 7 - The edge on these is nice though I don't get the 'hot knife through butter' that I see on the feather blades. After the second pass I'm about as smooth as I could get by a mach 3 against the grain (that led to razor burn though so I never went across or against with the mach). Durability: 7-8 - I can stretch a blade out to 2 weeks before it starts tugging. At ten bucks for 100 I don't try to push it and instead just change out the blade every Sunday. My facial hair is pretty rough and I've used some blades (sharky) that have lasted two shaves before needing replacement. Cost: 10 - $10 for 100 blades? Sign me up. At 1 blade per week that gives me ~23 months. These blades are the winner for me. Though I'm sure there are sharper blades out there, these are sharp enough and durable enough for a sophomore wet shaver like myself. I will eventually give feathers a try if/when the price difference is smaller. As of right now they are around five times as expensive and as good a shave as I'm getting now I really can't see a justification for it. Current setup: Gillette Fatboy w/ Astra Sup. Prem. Plat. Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood soap (http://www.amazon.com/Taylor-Old-Bond-Street-Sandalwood/dp/B00158S4RM/ref=sr_1_5?s=hpc&ie=UTF8&qid=1338213098&sr=1-5 ) Tweezerman Shaving Brush (http://www.amazon.com/Tweezerman-2801-h-Mens-Shaving-Brush/dp/B000G647Y8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1338213034&sr=8-1 )
  150. For most of my last 20 years I have used only Gillette cartridges and gels for daily shaving. They were fine and worked well. Over time I have seen their cartridges go from 1 blade to 5 now in the Fusions. For some reason paying $4 per blade always irritated me. It is not logical irritation but it is there nonetheless. I can imagine the product marketing guys sitting around a table and laughing at getting consumers to pay 4 bucks a blade. The irritation began growing and about 8-10 years back I switched to electric razors.<br /><br />The electric razors are (probably) the most convenient and cost effective solution for shaving. Oddly enough I don't shave with it every day.<br /><br />A year ago on a lark I bought a safety razor from Amazon and Feather blades. I bought this when the Feather blades ran out. I use about 3 blades/week of the Astras; note I do shave my head also 2-3 time a week. The feathers are definitely sharper. I was 1-2 blades every week; to compare I was going through 1 blade of the Gillette Fusions a week.<br /><br />What I really like about the Astras is that their edges are numbered so use edge 1-2 the first day and 3-4 the next. Feather should do that also.<br /><br />I still have an unopened 4-pack of Gilette Fusions lying in the bathroom. When I travel I take my electric otherwise I use the safety razor every day. As a shave it is harder to shave with it than with the Fusions. I have to be careful or I will nick myself specially when I do my head.<br /><br />I don't think using safety razors is for everybody but I now do enjoy shaving specially with a good soap. I wouldn't use the Gillette Fusions if I got paid for it.<br /><br />I think this year I may treat myself to an expensive razor and brush. Shaving is now no longer a chore but an experience I look forward to every morning.
  151. I've been using Astras every day for a few months now, and they're my favorite DE blade. Not as sharp as Feathers, not as dull as Derbys, good for 4 or 5 shaves, and really affordable. Some complain about the glue spots on the blade, but I haven't found this to be a problem. While I haven't sampled the entire universe of DE blades, I imagine it would be tough to find a better performance/price combo.
  152. These cut smoother than my Wilkinson Swords.
  153. These are great blades at a great price. They are extremely sharp and provide a truly smooth shave for several days or longer. The wax dots are my only gripe: they don't detract from performance at all but I am faced with occasional cleaning of wax build up on the interior of the razor when swapping out blades.
  154. Awesome product. The blades come in 10 blade boxes I think and stay sharp for a long time.
  155. Love these blades- have been using Derby for years but tried these and really like how smooth they are. I use them in a Merkur razor.
  156. I am a beginner in the luxurious world of double edged razor blade shaving with a safety razor. I initially purchased a razor blade sampler pack, and found that these Astra's are among the smothest blades I've shaved with. I know quite a few people love their Derbys, but, I prefer these blades because not only are they smooth but they are also very forgiving if you have sensitive skin like me. My shave set up includes Art of Shaving lavender shaving cream and a Merkur Progress safety razor.<br /><br />Pick up these blades - you really can't go wrong as they will give you a silky smooth shave.<br /><br />If you'd like a closer shave, I would recommend FEATHER blades. They are platinum coated as well for a smooth finish to your shave. However, please please please be careful with FEATHER blades, as they are EXTREMELY SHARP and one wrong move and you'll be in the Emergency Room.

  161. I purchased Astra and Derby blades because when I started looking into shaving with a Safety Razors I found the following comparison. Feather &#62; Bluebird &#62; Astra &#62; Derby. So I started with Feather. As I wrote in my review, they are VERY sharp; TOO sharp. They require just as many passes on my face as the Bluebird, but cut up my skin. So they were out as soon as I finished using them all up. Bluebird was cheap enough, but Astra and Derby are available as Subscribe/Save (WHICH I LOVE! All consumables should be S/S). This made Astra and Derby EVEN CHEAPER than they already are compared to Bluebird.<br /><br />I tried my first Astra blade last week and this week (I typically use my blades for 3 shaves). I found it to be no worse at giving me a baby-skin-smooth shave than the Bluebird. So, what's not to like about the blade? It's cheaper than the Bluebird and it shaves just as well. Of course, your results may vary based on your skin and your beard softness. My beard (when it grows out past the scratchy stage) is very soft like my head hair, so perhaps that's why I'm able to get away with a duller blade. Or maybe they're just as sharp, but don't waste money on the hard plastic blade holders like Feather and Bluebird do.<br /><br />Can't recommend these enough. Absolutely no nicks or cuts with the blade and it's nice and cheap. With the fact that I use these for three days, I've essentially a year's worth of blades in this box.

Definitely would recommend this to a friend.

  199. Let me start out by saying that a blade that works great for me, may or may not work for you and a blade that works great for you may or may not work for me. There are so many variables that one cannot possibly predict which blades will work for them. That is exactly why you want to try different blades to find which ones work well for you. This is exactly why you will see 5 star reviews along with 1 star reviews for the same blade. Take a look at how many good reviews vs. bad reviews a particular blade gets. If a blade is getting more good than bad reviews then you stand a better chance of that blade working for you, if it gets more bad reviews than good then perhaps you stand less of a chance it will work for you. But this is just an example of the law of averages. The bottom line is you have to try different blades to see which ones work well for you. Period!<br /><br />I have a collection of about a dozen different de razors and a blade that works well in one razor may not work so well in another razor since each razor presents the blade just a bit differently than another razor. Just another of the variables you will encounter in wetshaving.<br /><br />When I started wetshaving with a double edge razor I started with an Edwin Jagger DE89 razor and Merkur blades and used that one razor and one type of blade for about 6 weeks whilst developing my technique with this type of razor. Only then did I start trying different brands of blades. Some were worse, some were better. When I tried an Astra SP I was amazed at how smooth of a shave I was getting from these blades. I have tried Astra SP's in several different razors with varying results but always good results. One of my favorite combinations of razor and blade is a Gillette 40's style SuperSpeed razor with an Astra SP blade. In this combo I don't even feel the blade, it's that smooth.<br /><br />There are other razors and blades I like very much like my Feather AS-D1 with a Personna Medical Prep blade, very, very nice. But the Personna Med Prep blades are $.32 each and I pay only $.08 for an Astra SP blade. So you can imagine I really like these blades, not only silky smooth, but economical as well.<br /><br />I found a source of the Astra SP's for $8.00 for 100 blades so I bought 1500 blades. I get a week's worth of shaves out of an Astra SP blade so I have enough blades to last me 30 years. These 1500 blades cost about the same as 1 year's worth of the multi-blade cartridges so I'm way ahead of the game. My shaving supplies cost me next to nothing and I'm getting better shaves than I ever got in the past 40 years.<br /><br />Now please allow me to correct a couple of misconceptions I've seen in reading the many reviews of these blades.<br /><br />1) \\"These blades are not made by Gillette.\\" That is incorrect. These blades are made in the Procter & Gamble factory in St Petersburg, Russia, by Gillette. This factory has produced and continues to produce some of the finest de blades ever made.<br /><br />2) I see a few complaints about glue spots on the blade. It is not glue! It is actually wax and it has absolutely no effect on the blades performance. If I'm using a one piece TTO razor I put the blade in the razor with the wax spots up. If I'm using a 2 or 3 piece razor I put the blade in the razor with the wax spots down. Other than that, I don't even give the wax spots a second thought. I usually loosen my razor at the end of a shave and rinse the razor in very hot tap water, by the time I change the blade the wax is all gone.<br /><br />I consider myself extremely lucky to have found a blade that is silky smooth and only costs me $.08 each. But again, the only way to find out if these blades will work well for you is to try them. I would suggest buying a couple of packs to try before you make a bulk purchase. You may get lucky and find them as smooth as I have. Astra SP's are my go-to-blade. Good Luck!

The Astra blades last about 4 or 5 comfortable shaves. 2 passes using Shave Secret shave oil, splash on some cold water, a little Afta lotion and I am good to go. I was able to find these for $10 for 100 blades and free shipping, what a deal So find the blade that works for you through trial and error, however if you have a tough beard with sensitive skin give these a try.

  232. I just started DE shaving, and initially started doing it as a way to save money, but I'm really starting to believe that they work much better than the extremely expensive cartridges. I started with a sample pack and the Astra were the only ones that didn't leave me with wicked razor bumps under my neck and chin. They were the best ones out of the bunch, and I really enjoyed the ritualistic feeling of wet shaving, as opposed to dry shaving which I had been doing since I was a teenager. Anyway, the value of the Astra razors is really good and I like using them, but I'm also reviewing because I found the absolute best hack for using them. My buddy is a barber and he taught me that using just a little bit of tea tree oil on your razor makes them a) last longer b) prevent razor bumps and c) work as a bit of a moisturizer if you get the right brand. I stole this brand [[ASIN:B00LFT0CEO TreeActiv+ Tea Tree Oil Acne Solution for Advanced Acne Treatment - All Natural Acne Spot Treatment - Blemishes Gone or Your Money Back!]] from my sister, but eventually wore down and bought my own because I like it so much. The tea tree oil works as an antibacterial product, preventing the mini-infections known as ingrown hairs. It also worked well with keeping my face smooth after I had finished shaving. Since the oil worked I also bought the [[ASIN:B00U1J83SQ TreeActiv Anti Acne & Rosacea Treatment Sulfur Mask Plus Rhassoul, Bentonite Clay Mask with Witch Hazel & Aloe Vera - Refreshing Lemon Scent (1 Jar)]] to use as a face scrub, and this essentially got rid of all my skin problems. As for the razor, I'm not sure why it works better with it, but after a whole week of using it on my razor after I was done, they're a lot less dull than they would normally be. I give these razors five stars and I definitely recommend using the tea tree oil trick. It works so well!
  233. Best blades I've ever used for my razor at the best price I've seen

  235. Good for the price, I'm happy to have switched back to the safety razor.
  236. I am new to DE shaving. I've spent the past few years through college just using my beard trimmer to get the 5 o clock shadow look because I got ingrown hairs and razor burn no matter what.<br /><br />I had tried $200 electric braun razors, top of the line 5 blade razors, specialty shaving creams and gels, and sensitive skin razors. No matter what avenue I took, I would end up with extremely sensitive skin due to razor burn on my neck, and ingrown hairs all over my face.<br /><br />I had contemplated switching to DE for years, but was hesitant due to the &#34;learning curve.&#34; However, I have to say this is by far the best investment I've ever made. I have only cute myself once, and that was due to a sampler pack of blades I initially purchased.<br /><br />I gave about 20 blades a shot, and the Astra platinum blades were the best for my face. Feathers were undoubtedly the sharpest of the pack, but too sharp for my skin (hence how I got my first and only DE cut). After sampling so many blades, I knew this was the blade for me. 1 blades lasts a good 3 shaves, more if you have softer whiskers, but since they're so cheap, I switch mine out every 2 shaves just to get the best quality shave I can get.<br /><br />I bought a VDH handle from target for $18, and a highly rated shave soap (prorasaro?), a badger brush, and haven't looked back since. In just two weeks of shaving consistently every other day with these blades, my face and neck have completely cleared up. My girlfriend noticed and asked what I was doing differently and said my face has never been so smooth.<br /><br />I usually do a triple pass shave every other day, lathering up in between each pass.<br /><br />I know, without a doubt this is the blade for me, but I would still suggest trying a sample pack first. At any rate, even though my trimmer was definitely the cheapest shaving route, I could never label that as a shave. I can now enjoy have a smooth, blemish-free face all the time, and enjoy the shaving experience every time. It's actually something I look forward to every night. I shave at night, after showering, usually around 10-11pm. My face doesn't start feeling like sandpaper until about 3-4pm the next day, and doesn't start looking unkempt until the second day - this coming from a guy who has had a full goatee since 7th grade and a full beard since 9th grade. The shave is incredibly close, without causing irritation. All of these positive reviews aren't just blowing smoke. These blades are the real deal.<br /><br />My only quibble is that I wish each 5ct box came with a blade dispenser like some other brands do. But I just toss them in a small cardboard box until they're ready to go out.
  237. Great sharp razors at a low price!
  238. I bought 100. I used 100. I was happy to move to a better, slightly more expensive brand.

  316. I have switched to safety razors over a year ago. You don't need five blades on the razor for a clean shave; all you need is a sharp blade. And because these are so inexpensive, I have been changing blades every single day and have been enjoying a perfect shave every time. (Note: You don't have to change these blades every day. First, they remain perfectly sharp after a few shaves. I change them daily because it is my preference. And two, they have two sides, so you can alternate them.)

  328. Just look at the title of the product: \\"100 Astra Super Premium Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades.\\" Look at the pictures.<br /><br />Not everyone knows that platinum's market value is on par with gold. But as consumers, we're accustomed to the word \\"platinum\\" being used to describe a degree of quality... as in \\"he's a platinum member-- so if he wants a bathrobe made from panda, we'll hunt one down, stitch up a bathrobe out of it, and have it on his bed in less than two hours, with a bow around it, and an Andes mint in gold foil laying on top.\\"<br /><br />So one can infer that platinum, as a metal, is better than steel. When I look at this product title and picture, I see \\"platinum blades\\". In fact, I can't even find the word \\"steel\\" anywhere on the product pictures. You have to dig into the actual description to find that.<br /><br />Thumbs down for deceptive advertising.
  329. I have been shaving with a double edged (DE) razor for about 5 years. Like many people I switched to a DE razor due to the high costs of \\"modern, technologically advanced\\" replacable blades. It is my opinion that you get a better shave with DE razors or straight razors anyway. I just wish I could convince everyone of that, but it is hard to compete with those commercials.<br /><br />I have used the Merkur Super Platinum blades exclusively and have been very happy with their performance. What I wasn't happy with was their cost, but with most things I figured you get what you pay for.<br /><br />The other day when I opened my last pack of Merkur blades I made a mental note to buy more. Of course, I came to Amazon first. Just before I clicked the \\"place your order\\" button for the Merkur blades I decided to look at some of the reviews. I'm glad I did because the reviews convinced me to order the MUCH cheaper Astra blades and give them a try. I was/am impressed with their performance. The Astra blades shave just as close as the more expensive Murker blades and actually caused less nicks too.<br /><br />One thing I didn't like about the Astra blades is the 4 little dots of glue that hold on the wax paper, but it seems to come off quickly in warm water, so I'm not faulting these blades for that.<br /><br />I was so pleased with these Astra blades that I decided to try other brands so I ordered a box of Derby blades too.<br /><br />Needless to say, I will more than likely be ordering more of these blades in the future, especially at this price. The Derby blades are cheaper so if they do as well as the Astra and Merkur blades, I'll probably order them.<br /><br />On a side note, you should know that I have a very thick, course beard that grows quickly. I have used the first Astra blade twice and it seems that it has a couple more shaves left in it.<br /><br />My only concern is how well these blades will keep in storage. The wax paper doesn't seem to have the oilin it that the Merkur blades do to prevent rust. (I'm thinking long term storage in case TSHTF)
  330. I find this blade to be a good middle ground, and use it daily. The price is reasonable and the blade not to sharp, it feels smooth compared to some of the others I have used. I use it for a bout 5 shaves and then they go to the recycling bin.

  333. When I dumped my electric razor about a year ago, I bought a sample pack of DE blades featuring all the well-known brands. After experimenting with them all I kept coming back to Astra platinum. They leave my face baby-smooth and don't cause the red, irritated bumps that some of the other blades left behind. Astra has since been my one and only brand. Now, that being said, just because these blades are perfect for my face does not mean they will be perfect for yours. Your face may be better suited to Derby, Merkur, Feather, etc. My recommendation if you're new to wet shaving: start with a sample pack and find the blade that works best for you.
  334. I had been safety razor shaving for about two years before deciding to upgrade from the dollar store brand. I purchased these blades about 2 months ago and am still on the first blade. At this rate this 100 blade box could last a decade. The only reason I didn't rate this higher is that the blades are much sharper than normal blades and require even more technique to shave without cutting yourself. I also noticed the blade had a bit of a break in period of about 2 shaves before the shave became truly comfortable. I've noticed this with most every blade I've used though. Usually for me the first shave is a bit rough, the next shave is better, and from then on the blade feels smooth against the skin. I recommend getting yourself a boar's hair brush and some proper shaving soap and bowl to get a good lather. Superior blades need the superior lubrication of a good lather that the canned stuff just can't match.<br /><br />Altogether I'd say these blades are a great value. You won't be running out any time soon, and you'll be getting superb shaves for a very long time. If you use a Double Edged safety razor, then Astra could be a good upgrade from the cheaper blades. If you're using cartridge razors, then I highly recommend you pick up a safety razor then a pack of Astra blades and learn how to shave like a man.

  344. I bought these because I decided to give my dad's old safety razor a turn. I'd had it for years, just sitting in the medicine cabinet. Recently, there has been a resurgence of interest in the single blade, double-edge safety razor, so thought it would be interesting to compare with the multi-blade modern shaver I've been using for years.<br /><br />My dad's brass shaver is probably from the 1940s. You turn a knob at the bottom of the handle, and the top opens and swings up so that the blade can be slipped over it onto the stem. Another twist and the top swings back down into place to secure the razor in place.<br /><br />First off, the slot in the center of the razor does not exactly match the stem, so the fit is not perfect, and I have to wrestle the blade into position. And who wants to wrestle with a very sharp razor blade? I thought that all safety blades had the same size slot in the middle. Guess not.<br /><br />Once in the shaver, the blade shaves okay. Not as close for me as the triple-blade Gillette Mach 3. Nor did these blades last as long for me as the Mach 3s. Everyone's face is different, but that's my experience.<br /><br />Could be the shaver, but seems like shaving technology really has advanced, and I found I had to be a LOT more careful with this shaver than the modern style. Got a lot more nicks and cuts. A shaving cut is something I hadn't experienced in years.<br /><br />I used these with a lather frothed up with a shaving brush and Taylor Avocado shaving cream.<br /><br />So, I'm sorry to say that I've gone back to the Mach 3. I wish I'd only bought a small pack, but the 100 razor pack seemed so much more economical. Only wish I could think of another practical use for them now. )-:
  345. These are sharp, smooth and inexpensive double edge blades. Recommended. And if you still use a cartridge razor, throw it in the trash and get yourself a Merkur, Muhle, or Edwin Jager razor.
  346. like it so far, haven't tried other brands yet but this thing works great. I get 2-3 days of shaving with one blade (I feel like I can even push it more, but I don't want to.)
  347. I've bought quite a number of the variety packs which some of those blades work well. Based on the previous reviews for Astra Superior Platinum; sharp, excellent blades, etc, I have to say I am very disappointed. I don't think my face or whiskers are dense or hard to shave. I have always had close shaves over the past years, even testing the various blades. Sometimes you find the nice sharp blades, they just don't last but a few shaves. The Astra Superior Platinum blades don't even feel or seem sharp the 1st time I use them. I am on my 3rd blade now, 2 weeks shaving 5 days per week. Even with a brand new blade, part of my neck whiskers are barely touched. They are shorter in length, however they don't seem to grab those whiskers like most of the other blades do. I wouldn't recommend these blades at all, even with the very first shave. I use a boar hair brush and the same Taylor of Old Bond Street shaving cream which is excellent.<br /><br />No matter 100 blades for $9.00, I bought the blades based on reviews of how sharp the blades are. So with a Merkur DE razor I thought this blade was my solution. Not the case and I've been using DE razors for about a year now.<br /><br />Not sure what I am missing here that all of these folks are RAVING about how sharp the blades are? Did I get a bad batch? Honestly with every other blade I've used, the front part of my neck has always been cleanly shaven. With these blades stubble, stubble and stubble exists.
  348. These are by far the most forgiving blades I've tried so far. They do not burn, but they go dull quite fast. I can only shave for about a week, every day or so.My favorites are still Wilkinson Sword. After 3 weeks of heavy abuse, they are still sharp.
  349. I have been using Derby's for the past few weeks and while those are nice blades, the Astras do seem to be sharper and work with my face better. Very smooth shave out of my Edwin Jagger DE. No pulling or tugging...just nice, beard slicing performance at a great price per blade.<br /><br />I haven't had any nicks or weepers so far and the seller shipped them fast as lightning. Very good service/highly recommended.
  350. The Astra SP (Superior Platinum) blades are great blades, in my opinion. As always, blade preference switches from person to person, but these ones here are loved by many. Smooth, sharp, and cheap. The most important thing is smoothness. For beginners and sensitive face folk, the smoothness factor is the most important variable in your choice of a purchase. Go pick up a Feather blade and test these two side by side. No doubt the Feather will feel sharper, but it'll usually leave people with nicks and a blade-whipped face. The Astra SP is decently forgiving, smooth on the face, and pretty much the sharpest blade I have found that retains the smooth feel. If you are a beginner looking for a starter blade, try a sample pack or a pack of Derby blades. Derbys are not the sharpest around (all blades are sharp, but hopefully you know what I mean), but are very forgiving and smooth. Once you've mastered technique, come and check out these bad boys. Cost effective and efficient!
  351. These razor blades are awesome--just sharp enough, but not so sharp that you slice your face open every time you lightly snag the razor on some contour of your skin. Out of a sampler containing Astra, BlueBird, Feather, Gillette 7o'clock (super and platinum), Gillette Goal, Vidyut (super and platinum), Trig, Derby, and maybe a couple others, my favorites by far were Astra and Gillette. Of those two, the Astra were the cheapest and easiest to find.
  352. You can't beat the amount of blades for the price. Makes shaving very cheap. Blades are extremely sharp, which makes for a nice smooth shave. These don't irritate your skin like other blades and cause redness or bumps, but thats just for my skin as everyone has a different skin type. I highly recommend these blades.
  353. These blades are fantastic in my 1959 Gillette Fatboy *and* in a brand new Edwin Jagger DE89lbl safety razor. The shave is smooth and the blades last for a good 5 shaves before starting to \\"tug\\". Some people have complained about the gummy spots on one side of the blade. My guess is that it's used to hold the paper wrappers in place (while in the package) which helps keep moisture out. My fix is to simply put the gummy \\"side up\\" in the razor - no hair will get stuck on it then and cleaning is as simple as a few swishes in the sink.<br /><br />All in all, these blades are excellent. I will certainly be buying them again.
  354. Been DE shaving for 2 months now, first bought a pack of blades that came with all the popular brands, there were 3 that stood out, Feather, 7-oclock (blue) and these.   358. Razors are a personal choice. Some people have coarse hair. Some people have sensitive skin. That describes me and this razor works for me. When you are starting out with shaving using a safety razor, I highly recommend buying a sampler kit to see what works for you before you buy a supply of any one razor. What works for someone else may not work for you, and if I had went with the first (or second or third...) razor I had tried, I probably would have given up and went back to an electric razor. Some were too sharp and it too easy to draw blood or otherwise cause irritation, others were too dull and pulled hair. For me, this was the Goldilocks razor.

These safety razors are so cheap, I can put in a new one every few days if I wanted to and still have one $10 box last a year or more. I personally have to shave every business day for work. Sometimes I get the weekend off from shaving. But, with the newer razor I would start to end of with razor bumps, no matter the preshave oils, or shaving creams that I used. Its all from how close they get, and that they are taking the hair below the skin.<br /><br />I first started with a multi-pack of razors, that included I believe 18 different brands or styles of safety blades. I found that some brands did not work with my face or hair. Causing me to get more nicks than normal. I would only need one try with that blade to rule it out.<br /><br />I am now down to three brands and styles that I rotate between. The Gilette 7 0'clock Platinum, Personna Platinum, and Astra Platinum. I find all of these work wonderfully for me. And I personally only use them for 3 or 4 shaves, and then put a new one on. The cost is so much cheaper than any other blades out there for the more modern razors.

  504. I'm about a month new to DE shaving, and I'll never go back. However, the road hasn't always been easy. Getting the proper technique down has occasionally been a painful test of trial and error. I heeded the recommendation to buy a sampler pack of blades. There were 7 different blades of some of the most-asked-for and most expensive. After much experimenting with all of the blades and techniques, I found that the expensive \\"super premium platinum\\" etc. etc. blades like feathers and bluebirds consistently ate my face up and turned it into ground chuck no matter what I did. They're simply too sharp, which seems like an oxymoron. The regular, \\"cheaper\\" blades all smoothly shaved my face without irritation or nicks (for the most part). Of all of them, I settled between Derby's and these Astras. In testing them both out several times during the same shave, I came to the following conclusion: Derby's are a gentler shave, but they also don't cut as close. These Astras feel a little harsher, but they are a noticeably closer shave than the Derby's, which outweighs the 2 cents I'd be saving if I went with Derby's. So this will be my blade of choice (and thankfully so, because Feathers can run in the .40/blade range, even for packs of $100).

  515. (My review of the Astra blade is contained herein.) Here's how to shave: Think of two possible end results: They are (to use the phrases you see on the forums) a “Baby's Butt Smooth” shave (BBS for short – 3 passes), and a “Socially Acceptable Shave” (SAS – 2 passes). Are you getting married today? Consider doing a 3-pass BBS. For the other 99% of your life, do a 2-pass SAS shave. Also (and this will sound like heresy to some): You don't need to use a shaving brush. Why? Because it's wasteful, and not worth the effort. Most important things to remember: - Hydrate your facial hair before cutting it. The best time to shave is after a shower – it is believed that human hair is harder to cut than copper of the same width. Hydrating the hair makes it way easier to cut. - Keep your blade bone-dry between usages. Loosen the razor, dry the blade with a hair dryer, and keep it in another room away from moisture. Corrosion is the biggest factor in blade degradation. Here is how I shave: - Shower - Fill sink with warm water. Don't make it any hotter than you need! Heat removes moisture from your skin. The water temperature of your shower, and your shave, should be as close to cold as you can stand. For shaving, that means warm water. Filling the sink not only uses less water than running the tap while you shave - it keeps the heat of the water you put on your face, and the heat of your metal razor, consistent. - On damp face, apply a light layer of fragrance-free [[ASIN:B000GAXILM Lubriderm Daily Moisture Lotion for Normal to Dry Skin, Fragrance Free, 16 Ounce (Packaging May Vary)]] (layer 1) - Wet face with warm water from the sink (layer 2) - With fingers, apply [[ASIN:B000FQ2C8M Kiss My Face Moisture Shave, Fragrance Free, 11 oz]] (layer 3) - Make first pass. Remind yourself that this first pass is a rough draft. -- I use a Merkur Long Handled Safety Razor (simple, easy to grip when wet) -- Astra is my preferred blade, the best balance between sharpness and smoothness that I've found. I also like PolSilver Super Iridium. I've tried Feather (ultra-sharp, but unforgiving), Derby (awful - stay away), Merkur (too dull), CVS house brand (not at all bad, actually), and a couple others I've forgotten. - Mentally repeat the word “light, light, light...” to yourself while shaving. Apply ZERO muscular pressure on your face. The weight of the razor should do ALL of the work. --With the grain, against the grain, or sideways to grain? On this first pass, do what feels right, but err on the side of with the grain. - Empty sink / rinse face / refill sink. - Apply more Moisture Shave (layer 3) - Make second – and LAST – pass. Take your time. The only difference from first pass is that you may carefully go over challenging areas one extra time, MAYBE two extra times. Be a bit more thorough. Get everything. Again, mentally repeat the word “light, light, light...” to yourself while shaving. Again, apply ZERO muscular pressure. -- Go against the grain. - You're done. If you feel like you could have done better in some areas, let it go, and try to do better next time. - Dry the razor / razor blade with a hair dryer, store it in another room if you can. - Remember – the goal is not to have the most incredibly close shave every day of your life; the goal is to have a good, SAS with NO RAZOR BURN and NO NICS OR CUTS WHATSOEVER. None. Zero. You want your face to feel like you could do it again in one hour – like you DIDN'T EVEN SHAVE. This is something you'll never feel after raking your face with one of these multi-blade systems they sell, and it's something you also won't feel if you cut up your face trying to do a 3-pass BBS. You'll notice that there is no mention of using a shaving brush. That's because the supposed “benefit” of applying lubrication with a brush (“it raises the hair up, prepares the hair, blah blah blah”) is not remotely worth the cost (the time it takes to do it, the waste of lubrication whichstays in the brush and goes down the drain, the time spent cleaning the brush and bowl after). Simply put, using a brush to apply the lubrication is just a time-consuming, lubrication-consuming, mini-spa-treatment thing. Want to prepare the hair before cutting it? Take a shower to hydrate it. Finally, dispose of your blades properly. Don't just throw them in the garbage – that's irresponsible. Use a blade bank – they're dirt cheap. Cheap options include an empty metal Altoids can, or a plastic gum bin (another reviewer has one pictured - good idea!). And, of course, you can buy them as well. Enjoy your shave, and get on with your life. EDITED 9/3/15 TO ADD: Regarding my admonition against 3-pass shaving: In truth, I have exaggerated a bit. There are times when one may want to do a 3rd pass. If you have gone several days without shaving, then sure, a 3rd pass can certainly be helpful. But when waking up and shaving every day, a 2-pass shave is more than enough. Think of a 3-pass shave as a special thing; the exception, not the rule. For me, a 3rd pass – no matter how light and careful I'm shaving – almost always results in at least a little bit of razor burn, somewhere on my face. If you're going to do a 3rd pass just try to make it as “light” as you possibly can. Regarding the comment about going against the grain: DE (Double Edge) shaving means shaving with a SINGLE blade. (The blade is double-edged, and you are only shaving with one of those edges.) Because it is a single blade, there is no “tug-and-cut” effect, which is present on any multi-blade razor. Shaving against the grain with a multi-blade is hard on the face because of the tug-and-cut. Shaving against the grain with a single blade is far less hard on the face (it's cut-only). Additional tips: Use an old toothbrush to clean your razor between blades. Whatever lubrication you use will build up, and you need to clean it regularly. When your Kiss My Face pump bottle (or any pump bottle) stops pumping, you still have a significant amount of lubrication in there. Use a utility razor blade to cut open the bottle, just above where the lubrication is. When shaving, just use your fingers to get it out. Store this little “bin” of lubrication in a snack size sandwich bag between shaves. Finally: Many of the advocates of DE shaving seem to be preoccupied with proving how close they can shave with DE shaving (see youtube). I think this is misguided. (There's one guy on there who does four passes, and is bleeding all over the place. Ridiculous.) The fact is, if closeness is the goal, a multi-blade razor is always going to win that battle, because “tug-then-cut” allows you to cut the hair lower than the surface of the skin. But there is a cost: razor burn every time, lots of money, and lots of waste ending up in our environment. Finally II: If you want to see how much hydration can make a difference, shave right after a heavy work out (then shower). The half-hour or so of sweat will really soften the hair. Even better is right after a swim.
  516. When I decided to stop investing nearly $450+ dollars a year on fancy razors and quick shaves, I shifted to single blades and slightly longer enjoyable shaves, I never looked back.   518. I have gone back to double edge shaving after over 25 years of using the pulling, biting, extremely expensive cartridge style razors. I had become so used to them that I never realized how bad they were - double edge blades smoothly &#34;shave&#34; the whiskers off, where the cartridges yank and chop...including skin... That being said, after using a sample pack of a little over a dozen different blades, and finding the majority of them practically unusable, the ones I found comfortable enough for my skin where the the Astra Platinum, Feather, and the Gillette Blue. The Feather blades are great and just as sharp as most people say, and unless very careful, I would tend to nick myself easier. The Astra and Gillette are also sharp and very smooth, but I get fewer nicks with just as close a shave. It boiled down to longevity - I found I could get from 4-6 comfortable shaves with the Astra blades and about half that many with the Gillette before having to change the blade.<br /><br />Of course all faces are different, so as they say: YMMV.

  525. ... And I now have a runaway new favorite. I've been a double-edge/safety razor shaver off an on for my entire shaving life (~35 years and counting), and the Astra's are just like no other blade I've tried - and I've tried many. Up until now, I've been okay with Derby blades, but on a whim, and after reading so many positive reviews, I ordered these. From the very first stroke (using my somewhat new Edwin Jagger razor), I was amazed. Smooth, precise, and CONSISTENT. This latter comment is about the consistency-of-feel on both sides of the razor. With most every other blade I've tried, especially the Derby's, one side of the razor would have a smoother, closer shave than the other. With the Astra's, both sides are incredibly smooth-shaving.<br /><br />For durability, these seem completely average, and I'm fine with that. I get five good shaves (my face doesn't present a difficult challenge for a blade) before I dump the blade into my recently-acquired Feather blade disposal case (GREAT way to deal with old blades), and load up another.<br /><br />I'm now eager to try the Astra blades with some of my vintage Gillette razors. I'm confident the shave will be like it has never been.<br /><br />Highly recommended.

I use a mild razor with these to allow for occasional shape variations (very slight), then I go full throttle and shave clean in just two to three passes. Also, these are priced really low nowadays possibly due to economy over there. Anyways, this is a superior blade equal to the best out there in its own terms and in its own unique style.

It mowed down a week's worth of beard in one pass without clogging and I only used subsequent passes to get that smooth feeling in all directions. I've never been able to do this before - longer growth always took extra passes. UPDATE 06/10/2015: I just got a Merkur 15c &#34;open comb&#34; razor and the Astra SP blade also worked great in it. It is neither harsh nor too mild - seems just the right balance of sharpness and smoothness, it slices, no tugging. IMHO these are a great value. Only straight edge would be cheaper (but that takes more time/effort and more up-front investment). I am new-ish to DE shaving, but also got into straight edge shaving a couple of years ago. I can only compare these to the German blades that came with my Van Der Hagen razor and maybe I'm not sophisticated enough yet, but they both appear to shave great - better than the &#34;best&#34; cartridge razor i.e. Gillette Fusion ProGlide. I like the value, but the packaging could be a bit more travel-friendly, but perhaps that would increase costs. Still, the little 5-blade boxes are great. I am curious to try other blades and sharpnesses, but I don't feel like I need to. UPDATE 05/26/2015 - I have since tried a Wilkinson Sword and a sample Merkur blade (by Solingen) that came with my Slant. I have to say that my perception is that Astra is better - both: a closer shave and a milder shave with less irritation/injury. So far, out of the 4 I've tried - Van Der Hagen (Germany), Wilkinson Sword, Merkur and Astra - Astra seems best and Merkur seems worst (wow, really, Solingen?). I'll keep updating as I have Feathers coming in soon :) UPDATE - 06/03/2015. I also just tried a Feather blade with my Slant. The first shave was great and very smooth, the second - not so much. I am thinking that the Feathers are a one-shave blade. I still think Astras are the best blade AND cheapest blade out there.

I was back to the old nicks and cuts I had when I first started shaving as a teenager.<br />DE also requires a high degree of skill as the technique changes as the blade goes from sharp to dull.<br />Granted, 5 bladed razors are a bit ridiculous and the old single bladed bics were terrible.<br />But I've found that a good twin blade is a quantum leap beyond the DE razor.<br />And for an extra $5 / year for me it's worth it.

  589. I bought an &#34;old fashioned&#34; twist-to-open Feather Double Edged razor because I hoped that I would experience greater shaving comfort and a closer shave. My beard hair is not dense and heavy, but it is wiry, curly and hard to mow. I had also allowed myself to wishfully believe some current TV propaganda about how once popular double-edged blades really provided a better shave than contemporary Gillette or Schick or Wilkinson Sword multlple-blade razors and their costly cartridges.<br /><br />The razor I bought came with five Japanese made Feather brand blades. At the same time I bought this 100-pack of Astra Platinum Blades made in St. Petersburg, Russia--the old Leningrad of the defunct Soviet Union. They came nicely packaged in sets of five individually wrapped blades. The Amazon reviews were almost uniformly positive and rated these blades highly.<br /><br />I put aside the Wilkinson Sword Quattro (same as Schick) razor I'd been using since I bought it three years ago in Italy. It not only had four blades, but a fifth blade single blade specifically for edging in hard to reach areas such as right under your nose. With some lovely and refreshing Italian shaving soap brushed on in a thick lather applied by a fine bristle brush I figured I was all set and started in on my first luxury shave done the way Daddy did it.<br /><br />Using the Feather blades that came with my razor I cut myself in three places. I persisted until all five Feather blades where gone. With only one exception I cut myself in two or three places each time I shaved. I did exactly the same thing with these Astra Blades. I finally used about 15 of the Astra blades (and maybe a whole jiggerful of blood) before I was done once again, and likely now forever, with double-edged shaving.<br /><br />I have returned to my Quattro razor that has more blades than a reel-type lawnmower. It's still cuts me once in awhile, but once in awhile is a lot better than every day and every time I shave. The Quattro also gives me a closer shave, maybe because I don't start to tremble as I did when that double-edged slicer neared my face.<br /><br />Yes, blade replacements will cost me a lot more. I have decided to just put up with it. I may even save a buck or two on styptic pencils.ttro also gives me a closer shave, maybe because I don't start to tremble as I did when that double-edged slicer neared my face.<br /><br />Yes, blade replacements will cost me a lot more. I have decided to just put up with it. I may even save a buck or two on styptic pencils.

I have a very coarse, thick beard and shave daily, so I tend to swap the blades out every two or three days, with these I can usually get 4 good days out of them (lather, shave with grain, lather, shave against grain) before I notice a difference in how smooth the cut is.   620. It took me a lot of trying different blades to realize that the first blade i ever tried was the best one I have ever tried. I have read a lot of different reviews on blades, and most say that everyone has a different face, different kinds of skin and sensitivity, and types of facial hair, and this is why each person has to try some blades and see what works for them. I have sensitive skin and am very prone to razor burn and breakouts after shaving, and i have a moderate thickness of beard growth. The feather, derby, and shark blades were not sharp or stiff enough to make a clean cut without me having a destroyed face at the end of it. The green cased Gillette blade was a fine blade, just not as nice of a result as the Astra blade. The blue Gillette blade was so sharp that when shaving my neck, without even noticing, i had completely sliced through a mole on the back of my neck. I didn't even feel the cut or notice until i felt the blood running down my back. So like i said, every person is different and has different preferences, but what i have noticed is that Astra is the best one for me. I do not need to focus so much on my technique as this blade does a great job on its own. I never have any cuts or razor burn or anything when i use Astra. I feel a very smooth and even perfectly close shave with little effort or focus on my technique. one blade if cleaned off after each use and stored dry will last me up to 6-7 shaves, but since they are so inexpensive, i have no problem getting out a new one after only 4 shaves. i dont feel a need to risk using a dull blade when they are only a few pennies each.

  624. When I first bought my double edged safety razor handle, I got two free Feather Hi-Stainless blades with it. They worked just as well, if not better, than a brand new Gilette Mach 3 cartridge. I figured, for $10, why not? So I pulled the trigger, and shortly afterwards they arrived in the mail.<br /><br />The good news is, if you're looking for a blade that -works-, these work. They shave, and they shave pretty decently, but for someone who has thick facial hair and lets it grow about 5-7 days between shaves, these blades only last about 2-3 weeks before they need to be changed. Which is fine, because they are so darn cheap that you can afford to do that! However, having had experience with Feather Hi-Stainless, which could tolerate that amount of facial hair growth and still last about 4 weeks, I can't recommend Astra DE Blades over Feather Hi-Stainless.<br /><br />Feather Hi-Stainless are some of the best DE blades you can buy, in my opinion.

  635. I'm primarily writing this review in comparison to the Feather Platinum blades that I've used quite a bit. I bought this 100 pack of blades because they had good reviews and were cheap! Definitely noticed a huge difference compared to the feather blades. The Astra blades seem very dull and require much more pressure along the skin to get any reasonable shave. Oddly, it seems like some of the blades are significantly sharper than others. Sometimes, I would use them and think that it wasn't so bad, but other times, I would open a new blade and felt the need to immediately throw it out. I would definitely not buy these blades again. I've given them a fair chance -- used like 40 of them, but I just don't think my skin can take any more.
  636. Like always the package came in a very timely matter. That is what I love about Amazon. Since I haven't been able to find double edge blades in any local store it was nice to be able to order it and get it in two days. The product is exactly as described.
  637. I converted to a DE safety razor at Christmas and got a sample pack of 7 or 8 different brands. Some brands were too sharp, some pulled on the hair too much, and a couple were just right. The Astra was &#34;just right&#34;. I found the quality to be high, the blades were of consistent sharpness, and at this price and swapping them out once a week lasts me 2 years for far less than disposable or even replacement blades for an electric.<br /><br />Of course there are a lot of different types of hair out there, so I suggest starting with a sample pack to see what works for you. And even if you do buy the pack of 100, and it doesn't work out, then you really aren't out a whole lot anyway.

  656. good set of blades for nice cut. I change after two shaves.
  657. I know many people will praise the Feather blades but I find Feather blades to be surgically sharp. Too sharp to give a comfortably smooth shave. The Astras actually give me a better shave at a cheaper cost.<br /><br />With Feather blades, I feel like they doubled down on the cutting edge at the expense of the quality of the shave. By that, I mean that, yes, Feathers are the sharpest blade you can buy but it not only cuts me more but seems to give an inferior shave because it's so harsh on those troublesome areas like the Adam's Apple and just under the chin. I simply can't get a complete shave in these areas that Astras can.<br />I used to be on the Feather bandwagon but after trying a sample pack that included Astras I can't go back to Feathers. Don't get me wrong. Feathers are amazing for shaving a flat surface but fall short on facial and body contours.<br /><br />The only complaint I have against Astras isn't really something that bothers me but this is a review so I must be critical. The Astras are wrapped with wax dots that hold the paper wrapping around them. After some use of Astra blades you'll notice that the wax builds up in the safety razor and you'll periodically have to clean it. It's not a big deal since safety razors are stainless steel but it's something I know some people gripe about. When I consider the superior shave and rear price I'm receiving, a little wax isn't anything to worry about.<br />Another thing I like about these blades is they ship from within the US. Feathers are Japanese and ship from Singapore. You will wait quite a long time as anyone that has ordered anything from Hong Kong can attest to.<br /><br />I was skeptical of using any product that is made in the former Soviet Union but I've quickly realized that Astras are superior in giving a superior shave. They aren't the sharpest blade but they don't need to be. These blades excel in giving you the cutting edge you need without giving you those nicks and that itchy burning sensation you get from Feather blades.<br /><br />I have personally used Silver Blues, Astra, 7 o'clock, Big Ben, Derby, Bic, Nacet, Feather Hi-stainless, Nacet Stainless, and Blue Bird.<br />Not going to pretend these are the best for everyone but I would say they're a great choice for most. Please don't buy these standalone blades until you buy a sample pack. I bought a sample pack of 50 that had 10 different brands. It's expensive but you'll thank yourself ok the end when you find what works. Good luck everyone!!!
  658. If you're a real man's man who likes a clean shaven face, these razors are for you. Your rugged man face will thank you for it.
  659. In both cases I changed the blade in the middle of my shave to a Wilkinson Sword blade which glided across my face, leaving me with a close, comfortable shave. My friend just gave me a box of 5 to try out, these blades are sooooooooooo sharp no drag at all. no irritation. these are now my go to blades. with the Dorco blades I have been unable to get a really close shave on my upper lip or around my mouth and chin. Ive only shaved once with the blade so far so i cant comment on longevity of a blade right now.....but with a shave this close at this price with no discomfort? Worth it.
  748. I preface my review with the disclaimer that blades are an entirely personal preference. What works for me may not work for you. With that said, these are the best blades I've encountered. They are extremely sharp and durable. I find myself making fewer passes when I use these blades because they are performing so well. Before committing to any particular brand of blades I suggest purchasing a sampler pack. If you come to the same conclusion as I did then these are a solid buy.

  754. These blades are brilliant, but not many people have heard of it. I picked up a sample pack of razors when I got my safety razor. Blades are sharp enough to give clean shave and last for around 5-7 shaves. Every so often you'll get one that isn't quite up to snuff, but at less than 10 cents a blade you can afford to lose a few.<br /><br />With 100 blades in this pack, I'm pretty set on blades well into the next year. Be sure to try and make sure this blade will work well with you first though. The $12-15 you shell out for a sample pack will be worth it in the long run to finding which blade you prefer. That said, I think this blade will work quite well with most people.

  759. As has been so common with these reviews, I'm coming from the expensive world of cartridge razors. I noticed that the newer generation not only gave me razor burn, didn't give me a close shave, were a pain to keep clean but was lucky to get two shaves out of a cartridge. I was totally fed up with mediocre shaves that cost a fortune.<br /><br />I started looking for alternatives and found that a lot of men are converting to old school double edged safety razors for shaving. The more I looked the more men were raving about how great their shaves are and how much they're saving.<br /><br />I picked up a starter Boss set that includes the razor, badger brush and a stand. I needed blades and stumbled across the Astra Platinum blades. I read all the reviews and looked at the price. It was a no brainer choice. 100 blades for between $10-$12? That's insane.<br /><br />The blades are very sharp and give an excellent shave. I don't shave daily so when I shave it's thicker. The blades glide right through without razor rash. if you shave properly and let the razor do all the work, these blades make quick work of a rough beard.<br /><br />I get 3 shaves out of a blade. You may get less or more but for me I tried to go to a 4th and didn't like the result. I'm getting 50% more shaves out of the DE safety system than I was with a cartridge anyway. Plus at around $0.10-$0.12 a blade It way cheaper than the multi blade junk out there.<br /><br />With as good as these blades are, how well they're priced, you can afford to get a better razor and brush because it will literally pay for itself sooner than later. I plan on getting a better brush and razor soon. Yet I'll continue to use the Astra blades. They're giving me the best shaves i've ever gotten. I don't plan on changing that. ***** stars
