  803. After years of spending way too much one typical razors, I opted to the safety razor route. After going through a myriad of websites doing research I decided to make a purchase on a relatively cheap safety razor, a Van der Hagen shaving kit, and these razors. Suffice to say, I'll be purchasing these again. At first, I cut myself up quite a bit when first starting- a combination of getting used to a safety razor and these specific blades. After a little over a week my skin was comfortable and experiencing the best shaves it has ever had. My line of work requires me to be clean shaven and after an initial with the grain shave I go against the grain (usually on a daily basis). I do not experience the discomfort or burn from blades I've used in the past. I change out the blade whenever I encounter a great than average \\"tug\\" while shaving. I purchased these a little over a year ago. I am now down to my last 4 packs (5 blades per.) I've saved well over $100 over that course of time if I were to buy traditional razor cartridges.
  804. I've been DE safety razor shaving since 1960. Two or three decades ago I discovered platinum coated blades (I believe they were called Platinum Plus). Once I tried a platinum coated blade I was hooked and haven't used any other kind of blade since then ... I find that platinum on a blade is literally magic. The past six years or so I've been using a platinum-chrome coated blade (made I think) by Personna. Its been a good blade and I can get two months of shaving out of one blade ... so I don't use more than 6 or 7 blades a year. I'm on the first Astra blade now ... I'm testing it to see if it too will last for two months. Update: I changed out the Astra blade for a new blade on Friday (the fifteenth of August) as planned. The Astra blade did fine for the entire two month period and provided a close shave even on the last day. It did as good a job as any blade I've ever used. There are many good DE safety razor blades that one can buy ... and the Astra is one of them. I'd be perfectly happy to buy a 100 blade pack of Astra blades again. It did a good job for the entire two month period.

  831. My regular blades are the [[ASIN:B000GCSFWW Wilkinson Sword Classics]], but at half the price, these were worth a try.<br /><br />The Astras feel softer on the skin and more forgiving than most of the other safety razor blades I have tested. The blades feel thinner and more flexible. However, thinner does not mean sharper in this case. The Wilkinsons (and certainly others like [[ASIN:B0022R947O Feather Hi-Stainless]]) are much more aggressive and give you a closer shave at the cost of speed. Where you can blaze through a shave using an Astra, that same pace with a Feather will leave your skin a ragged mess.<br /><br />Astras are not as durable as many other brands, but half the shaves for half the cost makes these an even deal in my book.

  849. I have my man-hood back and in style with my saftey razor double-edge shaving equipment.<br /><br />Here's the order of things: I grew tired of my electric razor tugging on the whiskers and giving me nasty razor burn on one side of my neck.<br />So I switched to cartridge razors, went through Gillette products including Sensor Excel, Mach 3(Turbo), Fusion, as well as Schick from time to time.<br /><br />There's nothing wrong with cartridge razors. I can make each cartridge last well over 3+ months if I really try, including isopropyl alcohol used to clean off the hard water deposits.<br />They gave a decent shave, leading to satisfactory by the end of its life.<br /><br />Then I found DE shaving -<br />Pro:<br />(1) save money on blades [caveat - there's a small pay back period,considering you have to buy the de equipment including de safety razor,brush,soaps if you want].<br />(2) so much variety when it comes to soap/creams [more than 1/2 the fun for me is lathering up a nice smelling, slick/thick soap]<br />(3) closer shave. No doubt about it, you'll be going for that extra pass, to obtain your baby - butt- smooth cheeks.<br />(4) your partner will think you're pretty slick having a nice shaving bowl and great smelling soaps in the bathroom, and a fancy brush or two.<br />(5) regain a small portion of your man-hood by shaving with a potentially dangerous tool - the de razor blade! That's right, I have accidentally sliced myself once and proud of it ;)<br /><br />Con:<br />(1) steep learning curve. You'll be going at this for awhile, until you perfect your soap lathering skills & unlearning the bad habits of cartridge razor shaving including applying too much pressure. Yet it's worth it. Oh, and I'm still learning.<br />(2) obviously more dangerous. Be careful handling the razor blades. They are sharp as can be.<br />(3) time consuming. Eventually you'll be quicker. Yet, you do still have to whip up your lather if you're going the traditional route for thebetter shave. Or just use Barbasol or Gillette Foamy if you're in a rush.<br /><br />Regarding these blades. The expression is Your Mileage May Vary. Strangely enough, unlike cartridge razors, some de razor blade brands work well, others won't. You'll know it but the tugging feeling on your whiskers. So you've got to try sampler packs until you find one, or more, that work for you. These ones happen to work for alot of people and at a fair price. Good luck and enjoy your shave.
  850. Anyone who's shaved with a DE razor for a while will tell you that you have to try different razors to get the right one for you. This is true, and in this case I took a gamble and lost kind of. I'd had a pack of these a while back and thought they were ok, so I picked up this huge set of them. Turns out something's changed and I find I'm not as fond of them anymore. They seem to be less fluent across the skin on the strokes than I remember, resulting in a more than is common number of nicks. No for me personally, and I will probably stick with something else like Dorkos. Three stars because the product isn't terrible, and you get a whole barrel of them for a song.

  862. These things are awesome. They're the second single blades I've tried and hands down my fav. Very light and smooth. I shave probably 2-3 times a week and I probably get two weeks out of each blade. For the money, these are a no brainer. I use a shaving oil too, which is very affordable. Once you go this route, you'll laugh at anyone who buys Mach 3s or 4s or 20s for $4 each. Straight up highway robbery.<br /><br />I do concede that there is one advantage to the Mach 3s though: the shock absorbers. I have a mole on my cheek bone and with the Mach 3s I could just blast right over it and not worry. With single blade shaving, you...ummm...can't do that. I end up hacking it wide open about every tenth shave. Which blows because it bleeds a lot, but on the bright side, these blades are so sharp it doesn't hurt.<br /><br />Get these with a nice, heavy handle and you won't look back. Try an oil and apply it to a very wet, freshly showered/cleaned face. Rinse with hot water then ice cold water. A good lotion after the fact may not even be necessary. It's truly the only way to go.
  863. Really like these. Very sharp (obviously). Nice and smooth.

  877. Great blades. I use a new one every time I shave, so I go through a box of these every few months. Unfortunately, I believe there's a small quality-control issue, where a fresh blade will refuse to cut through certain hairs, leaving my skin &#34;pilling&#34; up around the hairs rather than cutting the hair instead. When I notice this (maybe once a month or so), I just toss the blade and use a new one. At first, I thought I might be shaving differently in those instances; maybe I was tired and sloppy, maybe my skin was being particularly difficult. However, since I have never experienced this with any other blade (and I've used countless others), I'm inclined to believe that these are to blame. Still, they do provide the best shave when they do work (which is most of the time), so I stick with them.

  883. If you're new to shaving, I would recommend trying a sampler pack of different blades (and keeping notes) before you jump on a 100-pack. OTH, these are so inexpensive that if they don't work for you, it's not as if you're going to be unable to afford lunch.<br /><br />Astra was in my top-3 (close second to Super-Max) and it's dirt cheap here on Amazon. I'd characterize my skin as sensitive and my beard as tough -- it's like trying to cut steel-wool. I had a beard for ~20 years because I'd only get 1-2 shaves out of a cartridge razor before they were too dull to shave with and even the best cartridge was never sharp enough for cross-grain or against-grain strokes for me.<br /><br />One Astra will typically last me about a week. Shave is FAR smoother than any cartridge I've ever tried. Until I started DE shaving, I honestly thought the &#34;BBS&#34; (Baby-Butt-Smooth) shave was a descriptive hyperbole, but it's actually very simple to achieve in reality with a good blade when DE shaving. Cross-grain and Against-grain stokes are fine for me, too.
  884. Super sharp great blade! Also bought feather's, merkur blades, and some others however these are by far the best and way sharper!
  885. Nice. Sharp. I use them for trimming thread from fishing rods I am building.
  886. The combination of affordability and performance are why I have rated these 5 stars. I use these on my head and face with no problems and because they are so inexpensive, I am able to use a fresh blade for every shave and still pay WAY less than what I was used to with the Gillette fusion cartridges (which I would have to suffer through at the end of the week as the blades will dull and tug).<br /><br />Here's the breakdown.<br /><br />Gillette Fusion Pro Glide 12 pk: $37 ($3.08 a blade). 5 face shaves and 3 head shaves in one week then throw away cartridge (otherwise head and face just started to get jacked up). 52 weeks a year x $3.08= $160 in cartridges<br /><br />Astra SP 100 pk $9 ($.09 a blade). 8 Shaves a week = $.72 x 52 weeks a year = $37.44 in DE blades . Yes please- I think I'll buy some more.<br /><br />They aren't quite as sharp as my Feather blades but they are more forgiving. I'm able to shave my face everyday without issue. With the Feathers, I start to get pretty sensitive as the week progresses with everyday shaving. I will still use the feathers if I need a super tight shave.<br /><br />Bottom line, if you go through as many blades as I do, Astra SP blades are the way to go. If you've never heard of DE shaving, do some research. I think you'll find that it just makes sense.

I get 4-5 shaves out of them before I notice them beginning to pull, and even then the pull is not that bad. I have an average to heavy beard, and need to shave everyday (if I have to work). I use these in a Merkur Progress razor, and a Gillette Slim adjustable. Works great in both. They shave similar to a Feather blade, but I find Feathers dull more quickly, usually after 2-3 shaves. I seem to get more irritation when using Feathers also. Feathers are also much more expensive. I have used many different blade brands to find the right one for me, and none come close to these astras for performance AND price! These come in 10 little 5 pack cardboard boxes. These may feel differently in different razors, but in the ones I use they are great!

  927. I am rewriting this review because after being able to compare these blades with more than I did previously I feel it justified a fresh take on them. I have tried some of the more expensive blades since then, such as Feathers and Gillette Silver Blues, in addition to the Merkur, Derby, Shark, and Personna Blues I mentioned before. These Astra blades are STILL my favorite blade out of all of them. The Gillette SB blades come close but the Astras are just a little bit smoother for me. Even though there's a lot out there I have not tried I just don't see the point if these give me excellent quality shaves. And for a third of the price of Feathers, which may be really sharp but feel a bit harsh on my skin, these Astras are a no-brainer.   929. Great blades and great price
  930. A reaction to the lubricating strip on cheap disposable razors turned out to be the source of a persistant rash on my neck, so I sought relief by returning to double edge shaving.<br /><br />I bought 300 Astra blades on the strength of reviews alone, which is a dangerous thing to do, but turned out okay.<br /><br />I have a fast-growing, medium heavy beard and typically do a modified one-pass shave: mostly down, but down and up in a few places. Call it a one and a half pass shave.<br /><br />An Astra blade gives me five comfortable shaves. The sixth is not uncomfortable but there is a hint of drag. Almost 50 years of shaving experience tells me it's time for a fresh blade.<br /><br />Six good shaves means a blade lasts me a week, since I usually skip shaving one day to give my face a rest. I should get more than five and a half years of use from these 300 blades, which works out to under five dollars a year. Nice.<br /><br />Here's a little info about my shaving routine.<br /><br />I use a shaving brush and a regular bar of soap. (By the way, a good shaving cup is a small, black plastic bowl designed for chip dip. It looks good, is the perfect size and shape, has a textured surface that helps whip up an excellent lather, doesn't clang when you stir the brush in it, doesn't break if you drop it, and sells for a dollar. I got mine for a quarter at a thrift shop.)<br /><br />My razor is an old Gillette butterfly type.<br /><br />Face prep consists of lathering, letting it sit for a minute, washing it off with a hot, wet washcloth, then lathering a second time for the shave. Lather touch-ups are done as needed.<br /><br />Each day after shaving, I remove the blade, shake it off, hold it firmly in the middle from one unsharp side and flick the other, as if playing a jaw harp. I then hold the opposite side and flick again. I also blow on the blade to help dry it. This little routine takes about a minute. I shake the razor itself dry, put the blade back in, and close the head loosely, not clamping it down tight.<br /><br />Razor and brush hang in a homemade metal stand.
  931. The price was great, half of what others want, or far less. So far I have gotten about six shaves on the first blade and I do not expect to have to change in the next week but that may change (see my review on the VDH Luxury Shave kit). The offered subscription is mind boggling; two-thirds or more blades per day in a six month or less period, astounding. Clark Howard will tell you if you let it dry they will last at least a month. A stand is helpful. I am using them in a vintage Gillette Adjustable Safety Razor.<br /><br />It has been about another two weeks or so and I am finding more out about these blades. I used one side of the blades for about two weeks and could tell that side was getting a bit dull. Then I noticed the blades are numbered, 1-4, so used one edge for a week or so, go to the next edge, flip the blade over and use 3 and 4. One blade should last you about a month. 100 blades should be about 9 years worth. Getting about 4 or five weeks per blade.

  943. Astras aren't the most talked about blades, they aren't the sharpest blade out there. But what it does provide is that perfect &#34;sweet spot&#34; of being &#34;comfortable&#34; yet &#34;perform&#34;.<br /><br />Only Feathers (out of the box an fresh) ahve given me a closer shave than Astra (pretty impressive for a middle of the road sharp blade). But of course, Astra is far more comfy and reassuring - you're never scared or think you will hurt yourself - and it's because you probably won't.<br /><br />Where the Astras shine and excel though.. is after the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th shave compared to other blades i've tried. It's performance and comfort is seemingly identical from shave 1 to shave 5 (most other blades, espeically the sharper ones - seem to have a very noticeable deterioration on comfort and performance starting with shave 2 - (must explain i have very thick, strong, coarse hair). And that is the Astra difference and why it's become my blade of choice over Feather, Personna, Derby, Wilkinson.

One thing I can tell you is that, unlike other razors, these don't seem to get those jagged edges that produce accidental cuts when they are old.<br /><br />So, let's sum up: These razors are (1) very economical, (2) as durable as other razors, (3) thin/lightweight, and (4) do not produce rough edges as they age.<br /><br />Razors don't get much better than that.

  962. Really low price for the quality of the blades. Just moved to wet shaving and this pack of razors will last a while.
  963. I cannot recommend these razors enough. While there are, of course, a wide variety of brands available, I tend to prefer the Astra and Merkur, both seem to feel the same to me. However, what puts these on top is the price and the amount. It's 100 blades for next to nothing in terms of pricing, and they should easily last you months and months.
  964. I buy a lot of blades and for the quality of these blades at the prices available they can not be beat
  965. I decided to get the Astra blades after ordering a sample pack and liking the 5-pack of Astras included with it. The Feather blades are really good too, but I am happy with my Astra purchase. They feel so much better than the Gillette blades that also came with the sampler pack.
  966. Having switched from Derby Extra to these, I'm amazed at the difference. Let's list the good things first:<br /><br />1. They last forever. I've used one blade for nine or ten shaves now, and it's still sharp enough that I have no reason to replace it yet.<br />2. They're at the right level of sharpness for my beard. With Derby Extras, I would cut myself because the blade wasn't quite sharp enough. With Feathers, I would cut myself because the blade was too sharp.<br /><br />I can't think of anything bad to say about them. The best razor blade I've used yet.

  970. These Astra Superior razorblades provide a quality shave day in and day out. I've used exclusively Feather blades for years but after paying premium prices I decided to look for a passable replacement. These do a fine job; definitely not as sharp but they do a fine job on just one pass, even better with two passes. They rank right up there with the Bluebird, not quite as sharp as the top drawer blades but they so a fine job. I've been using double edge blades now for about 28 years, from Gillette, to Schick and other blades from other countries. Most problems that I've encountered with the majority of blades have been with my shaving methods. I can get a good shave out of almost any blade, but some blades just take too much work - Astra won't. The glue has been a non-issue with me. I've used them in superspeeds, merkurs, probaks, and other two/three piece razors. p.s. I am not an advocate of the three pass shaving system. Usually, I do a with the grain, then an across the grain pass - an against the grain pass - even after the other two reducing passes - is just to severe for me, with any blade. Enjoy your shaves!
  971. I bought these razors over a year ago when I purchased a safety razor. I have gone through an entire package and have not complains. They cut extremely close. I'm on my second 100 count package now.
  972. Way better than the Derby's I started with. I can usually finishing shaving in two lathers now. No nicks either.
  973. Excellent seller. Fast delivery and the product was a terrific value and exactly as described. These are fairly sharp blades and qiuite forgiving considering.   1012. Several years ago I made the switch to shaving with a safety razor. Unlike many who review these products I don't pretend it gives me a better shave than my old Mach 3, in fact I'll admit it is usually a little worse. But I like shaving with a safety razor, so I've kept at it for years.<br /><br />Initially, after I bought my Merkur shaver I invested in a couple of years worth of blades by buying 100 blade packs by 7 AM ([[ASIN:B0017ZECA6 B0017ZECA6]] and Sharp ([[ASIN:B0017QSSIC B0017QSSIC]] both were entirely reliable and inexpensive options.<br /><br />After a few years when those ran out, I (foolishly) opted to try a new brand, hence this review. These Astra blades are noticeably flimsier, go dull much more quickly, and provide a less-even shave than the blades I'd used in the past. There is a glue residue left behind on all of the blades, something that I found on none of the other brands I'd purchased, and I'm just overall less impressed with the Astra blades.<br /><br />I let the high number of reviews, mostly positive, influence my decision to try these out, and I know my review is unlikely to change anyone's mind who likes these blades or is trying out double-edge shaving for the first time. But if you are like me, and satisfied with a previous blade purchase and wondering if you should give these Astra's a shot, I highly recommend you stick with the brand you know and skip these. I suspect that like me, you'll be very disappointed.

  1020. TL;DR - I've tried Derby, Shark Super Chrome, and these Astras. I like these Astras the best by far.<br /><br />Hello all. I'm fairly new to DE shaving, but I wanted to share my experience with Astras. I switched to DE shaving about a year ago, and I am never going back. I've used every Schick and Gillette disposable razor or cartridge that I've ever heard of, but I always had redness and/or razorbumps, especially on my neck. I tried fancy soaps, fancy face wash, fancy shave creams, and the like, but nothing made it go away. Finally, about a year ago, I switched to DE using a razor handle purchased on Amazon. I started with Derby blades, then moved on to Shark Super Chrome. Right away, the shaving experience with the Derby blades was more enjoyable and also more affordable (7 cents per day for a new blade vs a $2.30 cartridge every week). The Derby blades were a fantastic place to start, but on someone's recommendation I tried Shark Super Chrome. These blades felt even better, and I only had to switch blades every other day. Within a few months into DE shaving with Shark Super Chrome, razor bumps were a thing of the past, and redness was almost entirely gone. When I ran out of Shark Super Chrome, I decided to give these Astras a try, and they are AMAZING! After shaving for a few days, the blade is still so sharp that I do not feel any friction or resistance shaving my thick beard. I am still planning on trying other blades, but these are my favorite by far.
  1021. I got these for my father to go with his Parker razor blade and he loves them!<br /><br />He has pretty course hair and loves the results that he gets with these along with the fact that he doesn't need to change them as often as his old Shark razor blades.<br /><br />These are nice blades at a great value and definitely worth a try!

  1053. I've used many different blades in years of DE shaving. I found Astra SP blades a couple years ago, but kept trying other blades until getting so mired in blades, I stopped wet shaving. I missed DE shaving that I gave some thought to my best and most enjoyable shaves: Gillette Tech with Astra SP blades. I ordered 100 blades, loaded the Tech, and for the past several weeks of daily shaves, I've had no cuts, no razor burn, and no ingrown stubble; but I have had the three to four weeks of the best shaves.<br /><br />The blades shave close, but without the irritation of Feather, Med Preps, Super Iridium, Gillette Silver Blues, just to name a few of the blades that wrecked havoc with my skin. Astra SPs, a Gillette Tech, Arko shave stick, and a good boar or badger brush have delivered consistently smooth and close shaves. I have 300+ Astra's 'on file', and will likely order a couple hundred more--it's the only blade I'll use. I've given some five-blade tucks to fellow wet shavers who have become Astra SP users.<br /><br />I prefer the SP to Astra Platinum: The SP is much more comfortable against one's skin, it doesn't scrape, but it does cleave 24-hour stubble with ease.<br /><br />I prefer a close shaving mild razor, but I also want a DFS when I'm done; and the Tech with Astra SPs deliver. I use one blade for three exceptional shaves. This blade will go five-plus shaves; but I just begin to feel the blade degrading when I've tried a 4th shave. However, the blade will deliver five to six shaves, albeit with some degradation. Shaves two and three may be even better than shave one with a fresh blade.<br /><br />The blades have a little was on them. I dip a fresh blade in a wide-mouth container of alcohol and using my thumb and index fiber on either side of the blade, wipe the wax off before loading. Alcohol softens the wax, making it easy to wipe off before loading, if you're so inclined.<br /><br />Here's my a.m. lineup: 1973 Tech, Astra SP, Semogue1438 (boar) Brush, Arkoshave soap, and my post-shave splash is Thayers Cucumber with Aloe witch hazel. The result is an inexpensive but exceptionally fine shave. Blades, soap, and witch hazel cost me about $40 a year. I've had many expensive razors, including Merkur's Progress, Slant, 34HD, 34C, 1904, 180 Long Handle, and Futur, and a Feather AS -D1; but nothing is comparable to the setup I've been using. Techs are inexpensive, but efficient and comfortable, even on sensitive skin and wire-like stubble. Astra SP blades are a value; and I'd use them at twice the price.

  1082. So, I've been doing the DE shaving for a few months now and have got it down. I use a homemade oil, a shaving soap from the local store, and a good quality handle and badger brush. My handle came with these blades and I also bought a 35-blade sample pack that included Bluebird, Gillette, Feather, and a few others. I have course, thick facial hair and gave each blade type a fair shot (to include this one when I first got my setup). When I started, I was not a fan of this blade at all but quickly realized it was my technique and all I needed was some practice. I ended up using all 35 blades (5 of each type at a time) and kept detailed notes about them as I went a long. The last 5 blades were some of these. I was a little hesitant but decided to give them another shot and boy was I glad that I did. I think these blades did as good as the rest of the higher priced blades and actually better than most of them. I decided on this 100 pack which will get me 200 shaves.

  1087. I think I bought a 2-year supply and didn't realize it! I recently look up wet shavings after using an electric for years. But I have long been an aficionado of knives and sharp things, so I know the value of an extremely sharp blade. These blades seem to be well made with just the right amount of temper. They bend appropriately when I tighten down the handle and they sit perfectly in the razor. I don't have a really thick beard except for my goatee area. It's otherwise patchy. I can get about 2 weeks of shaving per blade! That means I will only be paying about $5/year for blades. Beat that, Dollar Shave Club! If you have a super thick beard, you might not be able to use them as long. These are packed individually wrapped in a small box of 5 and 20 boxes to a sleeve.

  1090. I experimented with very many of the blades offered on Amazon and ultimately settled on this brand for its sharpness, as well as its kindness to my face - no nicks.<br /><br />However, after nostalgically having returned to d.e. shaving, I developed an intractable area of ingrowing whiskers on one area of my neck which my wife has had to assiduously keep after with individual plucking with her tweezers. I've yet to resolve this problem, as the area keeps getting beset with more ingrowing hairs (very irritating). Thus, I have reluctantly returned to modern, expensive, disposable multi-bladed razors (Schick is my favorite brand), whilst retaining the preliminary brush and cream technique. There is a reason why technological advances have their place - never had above problem before nor since returning to the modern era of shaving, with which I do get the most comfortable and closest shaves available.
  1091. I bought these blades thinking in mind that they would save me money in the long run, and in that sense I doubt they will fail me there. A pre-shave of olive oil, lathered with Williams, put this blade into a 1968 Knack and the result was one of closest, irritation-free shaves I've ever had in my life. It felt, at times, as if there were no blade at all in the razor. Very little feedback. This blade just cuts smooth, however you work it. It's quite sharp, so use it in a mild razor.<br /><br />I don't know if the first time I tried it the blade was damaged, or if the QC from the factory is spotty, but at the price you can afford to ditch the occasion bad one. This can deliver an absolutely outstanding smooth shave.

  1134. ASTRA SP blades,<br /><br />These blades are well made and come in the medium range of sharpness, there are sharper blades, and that is not a bad thing. In fact its a very good thing because you don't always have to have the very sharpest blade to get the job done. There are other factors to consider as well like smoothness, skin feel, edge retention, cost, availability, etc...<br /><br />These blades are not really the best at any one category, but they are very good in all categories. They are smooth, well made, consistent quality, easy to learn with, forgiving of mistakes in your technique, and thus they are a favorite blade for many DE shavers. I have been DE shaving for five months and have used many different blades. I now mainly use Feather blades, but I bought these as my secondary blade because I enjoy using them. They are very good shaving blades. They produce baby's butt smooth shaves with my favorite Gillette Super Speed razors and that makes them worthy of being in my daily shave rotation. They are just the thing to use when your skin is a bit irritated or sun/wind burned. They are easy on the skin, sharp enough to take off the whiskers, and darned cheap to boot.<br /><br />I generally get five or more shaves per blade from them and have used them over 15 times in a vintage Gillette Tech razor. But that takes time to develop the skills necessary to accomplish that many shaves from one blade. Since changing over from Cartridge razors my face and beard have never been as happy. If your thinking of switching to DE razors do it!!<br />It takes a little while to learn how to shave with DE razors and blades, but once you do your face will look and feel so much better. I used to never be able to shave everyday due to irritation and ingrown hair, but now I shave everyday and I have had NO ingrown hair at all. My face looks and feels ten years younger and I get compliments often.<br /><br />So try DE shaving and don't forget to get some Astra SP blades! They are worth the price and perform like blades that cost twice as much.e worth the price and perform like blades that cost twice as much.

  1177. These are good sharp blades. I've tried a bunch of different blades and these are both sharp and smooth - a rare combination.<br /><br />Pros: Sharp, smooth, cheap<br />Cons: GLUE, only two good shaves, cheap<br /><br />I wonder if the reason these blades are so cheap might be because they are factory seconds or rejects - the reason being THE GLUE. A bit of blade glue, although unnecessary, doesn't usually bother me. However these blades have ALOT of glue (waxy adhesive that fixes them to the wrapper) - so much so that the glue-dot actually spreads to the cutting edge of the blade on most of the blades I have used. It doesn't really seem to effect the shave much, but it still bothers me. In my mind the blade edge should be clean and clear, and these are not. It also causes the blade to stick ever so slightly in my razors and it leaves some of the waxy adhesive behind in the razor and does not rinse right off.<br />Also I find these blades are only good for a couple of shaves. Keeping in mind that I have relatively sensitive skin and I almost never use a blade more than three times, so two shaves isn't bad - especially for the price.<br />That said, these are definitely top notch blades and you shouldn't feel bad tossing them after a couple of nice shaves. The glue is annoying but for the price even that can be forgiven. Four stars for price and performance. One star deducted for the unnecessary adhesive.
  1178. These blades are pretty good and get the job done. They're cheap enough that I can use new ones after every other shave. On the third shave they're already dull.
  1179. After I had used the Blue Bird and Astra blades for the first time, I made the mistake of rating the Blue Bird better for me than the Astra. I must have had a good Blue Bird or a bad Astra, because it hasn't worked that way for me since. The Astras are sharp and smooth cutting. They're the best blades that I have used and I believe I'll stick with them.<br /><br />The whiskers on my neck seem to grow in about 6 directions, so I have a hard time getting a close shave on the neck without causing razor burn from going over them with the razor so much. I've thought of going back to my electric with shaving cream, but the shave isn't quite as close. Using the Astra blade with a shaving oil under the shaving soap I do get a good, non painful shave.<br /><br />I realize everyone's face is somewhat different. If you're one of the lucky ones whose whiskers all grow in one direction, a lot of different blades likely work well for you. For me, I think it'll be Astra blades--especially given the great price you can buy them for.<br /><br />Highly recommended!
  1180. These blades do not work for me at all! Try a derby or a feather; they are definitely worth it!
  1181. Let's face it, we're being conditioned to pay 3-5 dollars for a cartridge to shave with that doesn't last any longer than one of these blades. At about 11 cents each it seems almost too good to be true-- but it is! I've used about 10 of the blades in the box now and haven't run across a bad one yet. Now, when I go to the shaving aisle at Wal-Mart and see what the other poor slobs are having to pay to get a decent shave I really feel sorry for them. Spread the word-- whether you use these blades or have another favorite there's no sense wasting your money just because the big shaving products companies say you should. And with all the money you save using these blades you can give yourself a good shave and take your special someone out to eat somewhere nice (well, at least to Sonic...).   1182. This was the greatest deal! I have shaved with ten, fifteen types of razor blades, and I ended up liking these Astras over the Feather blades a little bit. This deal was incredible, and I am set for a while now!
  1183. These blades work well for me ,they give me a nice clean shave and very few nick's to your skin.
  1184. The price is great, the amount in the box is great, but when I use it on my very sensitive skin, it feels like grinding my face against a gravel driveway. It is NOT sharp enough to give a tough beard on sensitive skin a smooth shave. It WILL cut, bleed, and discourage you from getting a complete shave.<br />I'm going for the Feathers: sharper, but less passes.
  1185. I used Japanese Feather blades exclusively for a long time, but I didn't like the high cost (still much cheaper than those ridiculous cartridges, but expensive nonetheless). So I did a bit of research and read a lot of good reviews about these Astras. These are now my favorite blades: cheap, sharp, and comfortable. As for how many shaves you get out of them, that depends on you. I don't wait until DE blades get dull; there's no point. I use them for three shaves and then toss them.<br /><br />Please, PLEASE do not throw old DE blades directly into the trash! Get a blade bank or put them into any kind of closed container before you throw them away. I recommend getting a cheap blade bank or piggy bank or even a used food container that has a closing lid. It will take a LONG time to fill a container with these blades, but when you do (after a year or longer), seal it up with tape before throwing away.
  1186. After working my way through many blades I liked(Personna red pk. and med prep,Wilkenson,Shark,ending with a 100 blade bulk order for BlueBirds) and some blades I DISLIKED(Feather,Merkur & Derby) over the last two years Astra has become my go-to blade. For the last 6 months I've happily used BlueBirds and decided to try the Astra's on the advice of a friend, because I had some left from a sample pk and kept hearing good things about them on the shave forums. I wouldn't say that there is a \\"GIANT\\" difference between the two. However for me the Astra's outperform the BlueBirds by a small margin in everyway(sharpness,closeness,smoothness and lack of irritation) and when you factor in the cost difference, the Astra's are a hands down winner! I would recommend trying Astra blades to anyone.
  1187. Year 2012 has been a double edged safety razor journey for me. I have tried the following razors blades: Merkur, Feather, Astra and Derby. None of them gave me as comfortable of a shave as the Astra. Using a Merkur 23C or an EJ89 razor I get fantastic shaves with the Astra for about four shaves. I do use pre-shave oil on my face and lather shaving cream to perfection in a bowl. The only blade that I could not tolerate was the Merkur that felt like trying to shave with a wooden stick. For my hair and skin the Derby has acted more dull than the Astra, and I have tried many times. The Feathers are great in the EJ89, but have to be very careful when using it in a more agressive razor like the 23C. For the price of 10 cents a blade I am very satisfied with the Astra SP razor blades.
  1188. These blades are super sharp, and super smooth. They are only surpassed by feather blades for sharpness. They provide the best shaves I have ever had.
  1189. I bought a sampler of DE blades and tried about 13 different brands and styles. I think my favorite was between Feather and Astra, with Feather being slightly better. But being able to get Astra blades in bulk is huge win making them far more economical than Feather, so I bought two bricks of Astra's.<br /><br />Of course favorite blades are a matter of personal taste. Having said that I would steer clear of Derby blades, also available here in bulk. I found them to be pretty harsh compared to Astra.<br /><br />Happy shaving!
  1190. These blades are SHARP. If you're new to wet shaving and with a DE safety razor be careful until you get the hang of it. When you're DE wet shaving it's all about the angles you approach your face with it. It just requires practice. I've been DE wet shaving all of my life off and on. I own 3 different DE safety razors and one of them is a old Gillette DE Safety razor that you have to take apart to install a new blade. My other 2 are butterfly openers. I just recently picked up a new DE butterfly open safety razor from Sally Beauty Supply for just under $11.00 And it works the best. Watch out for sellers here or on Ebay that have an inflated price on a DE safety razor. They are all about the same. These blades are NOT for the novice shaver. Take your time with these blades because like I said they are SHARP. I just got these the other day and believe me I have a heavy beard and it went through my beard like hot butter. Talk about a close comfortable shave. It felt like I didn't even have any whiskers after I was done. I'm talking about a close shave. The price here for these blades is righteous too. I mean 100 blades I am sure I will be able to get at least 4 shaves per blade. Here's a hint I picked up recently talking to a lady friend of mine. Go out and buy some baby oil. Don't matter what brand. Get a Dixie cup and fill it up with just enough oil to cover the head of the shaver and blade. After you get done shaving take the blade out and rinse it well under hot water. Put the blade back into the shaver and put it in the Dixie cup with oil for in between shaves. You will find that it will extend the life of the blade for extra shaves. The oil prevents the blade from rusting. When the blade rusts that is why it gets dull and your shaves become uncomfortable. Works well on disposable blades too. Learn something new every day.
  1191. Superior blades at a great price, I will not use any others. Does not cut or nick like some other blades.
  1192. I have used two of these blades so far and have been very impressed for the cost to value ratio its a great buy.
  1193. These are my new go-to. They last multiple shaves and are easy on the skin.
  1194. I have a sensitive face. Let me add, none of my razors have ANY writing on the paper.<br />You can see ASTRA through the thin wrapper, though. I thought it was printed on the paper<br />at first, I had to double check. The paper is blank.<br /><br />This becomes the only blade I want to put to my face!

  1203. Let me start off by saying I have tried these blades in several different razors and came to the same conclusion after shaving with each razor. I prepared my face the same each shave. Used the same shaving soap and shaving brush each shave. I put the Astras in and shaved with my Merkur 23c, Merkur 37c Slant Bar, Gillette 1956 Red Tip, Gillette Fatboy 1961, Gillette Silver Speedtip 1957, Gillette Slimboy 1966 over a several week period<br /><br />I found that the blades had a tug to my face upon first using these blades but seem to get better after the 1st initial shave. Almost like the blade needed a break in and then it smoothed out. I performed a 3 pass shave each time with each razor.<br />I got maybe 3 shaves from each blade before the blade was making my face raw and had to discard the blade.<br /> I never got a real good close shave with any of the razors using the Astra Blade. I dialed my Gillette Fatboy up to 9 and still the Astra Blades just didn't give that BBS shave like I had gotten with other blades using these exact same razors I listed here.<br /><br />With this said . Everyone has a different type beard. Some Coarse, Some Fine.<br />Skin types vary from Sensitive to having Alligator Skin.<br />Some guys only have to shave a couple times a week.<br />I have a pretty coarse beard and medium sensitive skin.<br />These blades just didn't work that well for me.<br /><br />I gave a pack of the Astra Blades to a friend of mine to have him test them out and he told me the same thing. He wasn't getting the same close smooth shave as he was used to getting from the Feather Double Edge Blades.His beard is not as coarse as mine so it really surprised me when he said they didn't perform that well for him. He tried the Astra Blades in 3 different razors. He pretty well mirrored the same results I got shaving with the Astra Blades.<br /><br />Blades that have worked SUPER for me are Feather Double Edge Blades !!!<br />I can get 8 to 10 shaves from a Feather Blade. There is no tugging. Just a clean, smooth shave.<br />I can't tell you how many reviews I have read where these guys are so scared of Feather Blades.<br />They tell you you'll cut your face up. I haven't cut myself using a Feather Blade<br />You want a Super Sharp Blade when you are shaving other wise the blades is literally pulling the hairs out of your face instead of being sheared off nice and smooth. Think about your lawnmower and cutting your grass. You want that blade sharp so it will cleanly cut the blade of grass instead of yanking it out by the roots and having a crappy looking yard and damaging the lawn.. Well the same goes for Double Edge Razor Blades. You want the sharpest you can get and you will get a BBS shave without tearing your face up.<br /><br />If you have a light beard and don't have to shave everyday then maybe these blades will work great for you.<br /><br />But for my money I buy the Feather Blades. When I factor in how many more shaves I get from a Feather Blade than I did from the Astra Blades I am money ahead to buy the Feathers and I get a much much better shave and don't have to change out the blades as often and to me that's less wear and tear on my razors.<br /><br />I have tried many, many different brand blades from dorco, personnas, wilkinson, derbys, merkurs, polsilvers and the list gos on.<br />The one blade I have decided to stick with is the Feather Blades. The upfront cost is more than a 100 pack of cheap blades but the cost per blade per shave is cheaper with the feather and the shaving experience much more pleasant.<br /><br />I can't stress enough that this is my experience with the Astra Blades and you may find that they are the best blade you have ever shaved with. What works for one guy may not work for the next.<br /><br />Guys looking to just start out wet shaving with a Double Edge Razor I would suggest buying a pack of feather blades, and then buy a razor you like. An adjustable razor is great for starting out that way you can get an idea of how aggressive of a razor your face and beard can deal with. Once you find your groove and get comfortable with your razor and are getting a good shave then venture out and buy some different razors. I wouldn't waste my money again on a Variety Pack of Razors. 98% of the blades are low quality crap filler blades just to make the variety pack look good like your really getting a deal. Too many guys buy a crappy razor and crappy blades and can't figure out why they aren't getting a good shave and give up.<br />Buy the best you can afford and you won't go wrong.<br /><br />To wrap this review up I always say.<br />Buy the best you can afford and you won't go wrong and You Get What You Pay For...t way you can get an idea of how aggressive of a razor your face and beard can deal with. Once you find your groove and get comfortable with your razor and are getting a good shave then venture out and buy some different razors. I wouldn't waste my money again on a Variety Pack of Razors. 98% of the blades are low quality crap filler blades just to make the variety pack look good like your really getting a deal. Too many guys buy a crappy razor and crappy blades and can't figure out why they aren't getting a good shave and give up.<br />Buy the best you can afford and you won't go wrong.<br /><br />To wrap this review up I always say.<br />Buy the best you can afford and you won't go wrong and You Get What You Pay For...
  1204. These are sharper than almost all the other blades I've tried except Feather. The packaging leaves four globs of glue on each blade, which I had to clean off each time I changed blades.
  1205. Blades are great. very smooth
  1206. Yes, as virtually everyone else has said, if you're new to wet shaving ... or simply changing over from a single or multi-blade cartridge style razor ... you really need to try one of the variety packs (there are several on Amazon). Pick one with 5 blades of each type, as you may need to repeatedly shave with one type of blade to determine if it really works for you.<br /><br />Obviously these Astra blades work really well for me. One question I see popping up often is the number of shaves per blade. I use each blade twice - once per side. I'm guessing I could go longer, but this way I always have a brand new edge with which to shave - and it's easier to keep track of how many times I've used it (important in the early morning for non-morning people). If I figure that I shave 300 times per year (probably on the high side), I need 150 blades per year. And at the price here (even without free shipping), I'm looking right at $2.00 per month to shave. If I'm desperate to save $, I'll skimp somewhere else.
  1207. I purchased a sample pack of blades and tried Derby, Astra, and Feather, among others. Derby was great to start with, as they aren't quite as sharp and give you a pretty decent shave. The 5 blades in the sample pack were enough, and as I moved to the Astra blades, I much preferred the Astra blades for shaving. I gave Feather blades a try, but they seemed to be a little bit too sharp. Plus they cost about $.50 per blade versus about $.10 per Astra blade. This pack is going to last me for a while. Once again, make sure you try various blades, because preference really depends on the person. Make sure the pack at least includes Derby, Feather, and Astra.<br /><br />Also, when you are first trying DE razors, don't spend $30 or more on your first razor. The Chinese double edge razor, which costs under $10, will give you a very good idea of if you want to shave with a DE. http://www.amazon.com/Silver-Double-Shaver-Nonslip-Handle/dp/B0050HO9MI/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1361225674&sr=8-1&keywords=double+edge+razor At the time of writing this, it seems to be about $3.50, I paid like $6. I still use this razor, and haven't felt the need to upgrade. At worst, you have a travel razor after you decide to buy a more expensive razor.

I ruled out the Feathers because they are TOO agressive, and I get more nicks and such with them no matter how careful I was. The bic may have been my favorite shave, but blades cost between 50 cents to a dollar a piece, depending on how many you get at one time.<br /><br />Sharks were the middle ground, but in the end I chose Astras because they are more easily accessable and cheaper. 7 to 10 cents a blade? With a good, sharp, coated blade? I can get a years worth of shaving AT LEAST for ten dollars. And its not a sacrifice for cash, my shaves are just as good as blades that cost ten times that much.<br /><br />Some people have complained about the wax the use to seal the wrapper. This wax is hardly noticeable and will rinse off before you even get a chance to shave, not affecting the blade's performance at all. Anyhow, I love them, and I highly recommend them.

  1232. I've been DE shaving for about 6 months now. Recently upgraded from a Merkur HD to a Merkur Progress. I am truly satisfied with the Progress but that is for another review. Now, onto the blades. Astra's are the 3rd or 4th razor I've experimented with. I hopped right into the DE hobby using Feather blades at first and subsequently shredded my face. I had no idea what I was doing back then. Now that I have perfected my technique, I know the intricacies of getting a BBS shave all over my face quickly and cleanly.<br /><br />The Astra blades are decent. I thought they would be my daily blades. They're a bit better than Dorco's and for the price they are the better choice than those. But I went back to Feather blades now that I perfected my technique. And these just don't compare at all to the Feathers. If I had a choice between the two, or a choice between a Feather I have used 3 times already, or a fresh Astra blade. The feather would still give a cleaner less irritating shave on my face. There is a dramatic difference in performance between the two. But there is also a huge difference in the price. You only get 30 feather blades for the price of 100 Astras.<br /><br />I get BBS every time with the Feathers. With the Astras I get dragging and irritation. A three pass shave with Astra's doesn't give me as clean a shave as 2 pass with feathers. Even on 3 day growth I can do a 2 pass with Feathers and get BBS. With Astra, overnight growth needs 3 passes. They just aren't sharp enough for me to give me a truly clean shave.<br /><br />If you are a newbie to DE and need to craft your technique I think these would be a good choice before getting something as sharp as the Feathers though. I shaved with these for 2 months before falling in love with Feathers and they helped me get my technique down.

I realize all skin is different, but so far, these Astras are the best razor blades I've ever used. I don't have particularly sensitive skin, but they don't pull whatsoever and I don't end up with razor burn to get a baby-smooth shave. The price is amazing too. I'll be using a blade every 2-3 shaves and swapping it for a new one from now on. No sense in using a dulling blade when there are 99 more waiting in the medicine chest and they're only $0.10 each. And as for the little dabs of wax in the blades everybody seems to be complaining about... They're barely even noticeable and don't affect the shave in the slightest way whatsoever. They're just there to hold the wrapper on, and a short blast of hot water immediately removes them, if you're so inclined to to that. I'm not. In short, I have no brand loyalty to any company, but these blades work great for me and the price was fantastic. I'll definitely buy them again in a YEAR when I run out.

  1256. I read a lot of sources, and came to the conclusion that there are 2 primary schools of thought for people getting into the safety razor scene when it comes to blade choice:<br /><br />1. Buy a sampler pack - try a bunch of options, see what works, then buy more of those. Pros - variety. Cons - expensive, and you don't know if it's your shaving technique or the blade that's an improvement.<br /><br />2. Buy one line of blades - Buy a bunch of one blade, try it out, learn to shave, improve your shaving technique, then try out another blade once your technique is good. This isolates the improvement to the blade.<br /><br />I decided to spend $ instead of $$$ and buy 100 of a blade I'd never tried, but that reviewed well.<br /><br />I've used 10 of them so far, and can get a good 3-4 shaves out of each one before I replace them. They're so cheap that I don't feel bad changing them that frequently.<br /><br />I recommend trying these out, and if they work, great! If not... you're out $10.
  1257. These are way better than the store band blades which are all I can find at my local pharmacy and easy less expensive. While I hear a lot about feather, I don't much want to pay 3x the price.   1264. Having good results with the Astra.

  1267. After experimenting with a number of DE blades from one of those mutipacks, I decided the Astra Platinum was for me. A DE blade is a very personal thing, so let me tell you what I was after. I wanted a blade that could sustain a good edge for a week of shaving while leaving my face as smooth as a baby's... well, you know. I shave with a Merkur Futur at the 2.5 setting and I have learned to navigate my facial hair grain directions (many for me) pretty well. I experience very little resistance in the blade even after a few shaves... in fact, there isn't really much of a pull after a week. I personally think these are some of the sharpest blades I've used. I definitely recommend that you try these blades. I'll be coming back for more! Can't beat this deal for 100 blades!
  1268. Awesome blade! great consistency between blades. Gives a great smooth shave that is pretty irritation free. I guess I should mention I use these in an Edwin Jagger DE89LBL.

  1279. I will never run out of razors ever again!
  1280. These revitalized double-edge shaving for me. I'd been using Gilette blades since forever, but they're getting harder to find and more expensive over they years. They also seem to be poorer quality than I remember from even a decade ago. I'd been switching back-and-forth between disposables and my trusty double-edge razor for a while, when I found these more or less by accident and ordered a box. They're delightfully sharp, flexible, and made with very tight tolerances and high quality control. I get a great shave every morning.<br /><br />I get at least two days out of each edge (they'd probably be good for 4-5 days per edge), so 400 days in a box. That's over a year of daily shaving with a far nicer blade than you can get in the shaving aisle of your grocery store (at least in the U.S.).
  1281. The blades themselves are fantastic. I love how sharp they are and that I can get a fair number of repeat uses out of a blade. The downside is that they have a lot of glue holding them into the wax paper and this glue remains on the blade after removal.
  1282. These are great blades for someone who is new to the wet shaving method. They are not super-sharp which is very helpful as you will minimize cutting yourself. I bought this pack of 100 before I found out about the sample packs and I was concerned that I have bought a huge number of blades that might not serve the purpose but these blades have never given me any problems. No irritation or shaving bumps and they give a very smooth shave. I would highly recommend them
  1283. I have been using a Double-Edged Safety Razor for about five years now. I started with a sampler pack, but as soon as ran out of blades, I proceeded to use the CVS brand blades, which I believe were made by Persona. I eventually decided to try Feathers, a blade that was widely praised amongst DE enthusiasts. They have given me over a year of good shaves, but one day I had the opportunity to try Astra SP.<br /><br />These blades are phenomenal, and about one-third of the price of Feathers. They are a hair(no pun intended) less sharp, but very smooth. My technique is now very good, so I rarely see blood from either blade.<br /><br />For the price, Astra SP cannot be outmatched. They are just as good as Feathers, very similar in my opinion. Buy them today.

  1300. When I started DE shaving about four months ago I ordered a blade sampler to try to determine which I would like best. Blades seem to be a very personal choice based on your razor, skin, and beard type. Samplers are therefore very helpful in determining what blade is best for you. Astra SP was maybe the third or fourth blade I tried and it immediately became the standard against which I judged the rest of the blades. It effortlessly sliced through the whiskers. I kept coming back to it. I even ordered a few more 5 packs of various other blades just to make sure this was the one for me and it obviously was because I just purchased 100 of them. I typically get three or four shaves out of a blade; I could stretch it farther but why when they are this inexpensive? These blades appear to be very popular with people that are new to traditional wet shaving due to their reputation as sharp but not so harsh as a Feather blade (Feathers seem to be the gold standard in sharpness). The Astras are much more forgiving, and a great value to boot. I am using them in a Merkur 23C and do a three pass shave. My beard is somewhat thick and I shave six days a week. Remember that good lather is just as (if not more) important as blade choice when it comes to DE shaving! Hope this is helpful. Enjoy your shave!
  1301. I could go on and on about how much I love these blades, especially after using up a trial package of Sharks. The Sharks never felt very sharp and I always felt like I was walking around with a half-baked shave. It sometimes felt like they would tug on the hair rather than cleanly shear it off, even if it was a brand-new blade. The Astras are superior in every way and the sharpness is immediately evident. Yes, the super-sharp edge has its downsides, I get nicked a little more than I did with the Sharks, but the Astras have never once given me razor burn, which was something I was trying to escape by switching to a double-edge razor. These are fabulous blades for the price at just over $0.10 each, and enough to last me for a year or more.
  1302. Only the second type of DE blade I've tried, but these are very nice. Sharp without being scary sharp, and they last for a few shaves, or give one very close shave each. The price is right, (12 USD shipped) and when I've tried more blades, I'll come back and write about how they stack up.

One annoying thing are the glue/wax dots they put on the blade for sealing the wax paper to it, I think. Sometimes it looks like it flowed onto the cutting part of the blade.On some razors they will leave residue on that you will notice when you change blades and is annoying to clean off. The Astra Superior blades are really nice, especially under 9 bucks... and no nicks yet. I have what I would call a medium beard and should be shaving daily based on how it grows but the blades I purchased handle my stubble nicely. The razor was a little under 13 bucks so once I factor that cost out I think I'll get about 3 good shaves off a blade so that's about 9 cents a week... under 5 bucks a year... for my shaving cost. Adding in a few bars of soap I'll likely get about 4 years of shaving for the cost of 1 year of replacement Norelco heads. Lastly, since it's the blade that does the work I find spending a few bucks more on them is well worth it.

  1321. If you're new to double edge shaving like I was a few months ago, listen up. I have some tips for you. You'll have to assemble some products for a quality shave. First, do like I do; get yourself an ADJUSTABLE razor. Why? If a blade is too sharp or it's not shaving close enough, you can simply dial up or dial down the setting. I recommend a vintage Gillette adjustable from the 60s like a Slim or Fat Boy. They're made from solid rolled brass and coated with nickel; they'll last forever. (Compare that to some modern razors made out of pot metal. If you drop it, it cracks.) Third, your double edge blade. Try a sample pack. Usually, they have the top brands included, and make sure one of the brands is the Astra SP (Superior Platinum). You probably read about the Feather being the sharpest. Yeah, they're sharp, but only for 2 shaves. Astra are smooth on top of being sharp; shaving with one is like a hot knife through butter. It feels like you don't have a blade in the razor. Good luck and enjoy shaving again. I wish you many baby butt smooth shaves in the future.
  1322. I consider these to be a great value. I'm not yet a DE shaving aficionado, but find these blades to offer an acceptable shave. I can only get two or three uses from each blade, but at such a low cost, it doesn't matter!
  1323. To be fair these are the only DE blades I've ever used, but they work perfectly for me and are definitely a step up from my old cartridge razor. I don't see myself spending money on new blades anytime soon.
  1324. these are the best razors i have used. i used Sharp brand razors for 2 year and these are considerably better. i love it! for the price it is a steal. if you,re looking to switch over to REAL shaving, as opposed to 8 bladed ( or whatever they are up to these days) clown shavers, i would recommend starting on these blades.
  1325. I'm relatively new to the double-edge shaving world. Was seeking a better way of shaving.<br /><br />I was relatively happy with the blades that came supplied with my new double-edged razor. After thinking about a huge sampler pack I decided to give these a whirl. I had read some reviews that these were good for guys with sensitive skin - which I have. I'm about 5 blades into my 100 pack and am so far very impressed. I can't really see myself trying anything else unless it's just for fun I guess? These work very well and I am expecting them to last me a LONG time. I use 1 blade for 2-3 shaves. I haven't decided whether 2 or 3 is the optimal number of shaves.<br /><br />Lastly, if you get them, pay no attention to the numbers on the blades themselves, they are just used in the manufacturing process.
  1326. After buying a variety pack with 8+ different brand types, Astra was the one that didn't irritate my super sensitive skin while barely nicking me. Even after trying other blades after using Astra, I came back to these guys. They are very sharp and give a smooth shave on my face. Yet, my neck and face are no longer left feeling on fire or irritated/embarassingly bright red for 2-3 days afterward like when I used to shave with the disposable Gilettes. Oh, what relief!<br /><br />Besides this benefit, the next best thing with this pack is the cost. For $9 you get 100 blades. Generally, I change my blades once a week, meaning one blade per week equals out to 100 weeks -- that's two years' worth of blades for $9!! If you're shaving with over-priced, crappy-quality disposables you'll win the lottery before you find a deal like that.<br /><br />On another note, some of the concerns of other reviewers I can empathize with. I really only get 2-3 shaves before I need to change the blade, which does seem a bit underwhelming. However, with the price, quantity, and quality for these blades that obviously does not deter the 5-star review from me.<br /><br />Interestingly, and on a completely random tangent, I read somewhere that the numbers on each sides of the blades mean nothing at all of significance. The interesting part is that I sometimes get a noticeably better shave when I use the \\"3-4\\" side of the blade facing up versus the \\"1-2\\" side facing up. Anyway...<br /><br />Last thing, brothers: one of the best decisions I have ever made was switching to shaving with DE safety razors. From there, one of the most important decisions a man will make after doing the same will be choosing which blades to shave with. As other reviewers here have pointed out, Astra may do wonders for your face as with mine. On the other hand, Astra blades may wreck your face while Derby will do just the trick. Before buying this, make sure you've been able to try out different blades in a variety pack. However, if you've found Astra to be your skin's pal, make both your face and wallet happy and buy this pack.
  1327. Not a bad shave on the first shave, second shave a little rough. I started replacing every shave or two. I do have coarse facial hair and am a long time feather user. They are definitely much less aggressive than the feathers but I find that they miss spots no matter how much time I take. Two passes a must for me with these blades.   1340. I bought these razor blades after using them in a 16-blade sample pack I bought from Amazon during my initial foray into the world of DE safety razors. The pack included various styles of Gillette blades, Feather, Astra, and several others. Out of all of them I found that Astra worked best for my skin. Most of the blades (all of the Gillette blades and the numerous 'no name' brands) irritated my skin due to being too dull. On the other hand, the Feather blades were far too sharp and it looked like Jack the Ripper had gotten a hold of me after every shave. Astra was the perfect middle ground, and the price (especially compared to Feather) was right as well.<br /><br />Ultimately, everyone's face/hair is different so you should experiment with a variety of blades to see which ones suit you. I know people who claim that Astra is too irritating for them and they prefer some of the ones that I felt were too dull.

  1393. It's always a pleasure to find a product that performs this well without any downsides. I put a new blade in my razor and got the smoothest, most comfortable, irritation free shave ever, all for about 10 cents. Unlike so many others, I will not bash the modern Gillette cartridges, though they have gotten ridiculous. They have long forgotten the form over function principle. My favorite is the Sensor. I still get a good shave from the Sensor and travel with one. And yes, the cartridge prices are a bit crazy, but if you like the simplicity and convenience, why not use them. My purpose for switching to a double edge safety razor was and is not about saving money. It was about saving my face. I've gone from reluctantly shaving twice a week to shaving every day, sometimes twice per day. I now like shaving and these Astra blades make my morning shave even more enjoyable. My first blade lasted for 6 shaves and I really could have used it more, but decided to make a change anyways. It's not fair to compare these Astra blades to Feather blades, as the Astras are much better on a daily basis. They are sharp enough, easily slide through my tough beard, and are extremely gentle on my skin. The Feather blades enjoy cutting anything in their path, skin included. They are not bad, these are just easier to use. I also use Personna blades, which are quite sharp, however they aren't quite as smooth as the Astra. Neither the Derby blade, nor the Merkur blade impressed me, but I still got a decent shave. The Astra Platinum blades perform equally well in my Edwin Jagger DE89lbl and my Feather Popular razors. I have no complaints at all and will use them and recommend them without reservation. I urge anyone in search of a comfortable, affordable shave to try these Astra Platinums. If you cut yourself with these blades, it is most certainly your fault.
  1394. The Astra blades are amazing quality. I shave about 3 times a week and one razor lasts me a month! The price for these is just unbelievable, It costs me 10 cents a month for good clean shaves. I use them in a Merkur long handle safety razor. The razor does start off very sharp, so the first shave with a fresh razor needs to be more careful. After the first few shaves the razor becomes perfect and I can do a fast wet shave without worrying about cuts.
  1395. The dispenser box is very handy and the blades are wrapped well. These don't like my face or handle, maybe both, but that does not deserve a down rated review. You will get your money out of this box of blades. My suggestion is to get a trial pack first though to see what works for you.
  1396. I did a lot of research on different blades before I made the purchase of these. My whole point of safety razor shaving is getting a great shave for cheap. These platinum blades are doing a great job!
  1397. I ordered this so I would have a virtually unlimited supply. The ones I have tried work fine. Sharp and smooth.
  1398. These are very good blades. As you read this and other reviews you will begin to realize that different brands of blades are good or bad for different people. It is hard to explain really. It is not about which ones are sharpest, most expensive, or made of the best material. I had tried two other blades before trying Astra. These ara not the sharpest blades but they are sharp and work best for me. They are so inexpensive I just put a new one in each morning. Get the variety pack and try different blades to find which you need.It may serve you well if you are thorough to read a few reviews for each blade type found in the pack. There are a couple different variety packs with different blades. You can read these reviews all day but as soon as you try different blades in the variety pack you will know which is best for that mug on your head. Best to also invest in a beaver brush, shave soap, and a stand to hold the razor and brush. The shave with these items is great. It takes a little patience to figure out which blade is best but the shave is good and certainly more economical. I got into this when I noticed suddenly I was unable to get more than a few shaves out of Gillete Sensor cartridges that were skyrocketing in price. I am not really cheap just can't stand it when a company does stuff like that.
  1399. I bought a Merkur razor and that came with one blade. In comparison the Merkur blade was significantly better. I used the Merkur blade I think for six shaves and barely cut myself or had any resistance. With these blades, although they still work fairly well, I found myself getting cut more and not as smooth of a shave. As the title says, they're okay. They're not so bad that I'm going to toss the 99 remaining blades. It's a value buy, you get what you pay for. Just ask yourself if you're ready for probably a year worth of shaving or more with the same blades if you're not satisfied... Maybe try a smaller pack first if they offer them? I bought for the value. They're fine but I probably won't purchase again.<br /><br />******Update*****<br /><br />After using a few more razors I don't know if my skin has gotten tougher or if I just got a bad first razor. That said my experience has definitely improved from the first razor (I am on my fourth I believe now) but I still would consider trying another brand on my next purchase as this was my first (aside from the promotional Merkur razor I received with my set). Although I am experiencing improved comfort with these blades I still feel I am not getting the longevity out of the blade I was expecting before having to put in a new blade for the same level of comfort. That said, for the price it's hard to beat the deal, I'm just a sucker for a good deal.

  1405. Bought these to try out as I've used persona and feathers already. I found these nice for shaving my head as they're not to aggressive and tend to be more gentle. I still use feathers and personas on my face though.
  1406. I am fairly new to DE shaving (started in December 2012) and have discovered (or confirmed) that razor blades are definitely a &#34;YMMV&#34; item. Based on several forum recommendations, I purchased various sampler packs containing a wide assortment of razor blade brands. Before this purchase, i really thought that a blade is a blade and they are all the same - I was definitely wrong with this initial comment.<br /><br />In my testing, the three blades that separated from the rest were Feathers, Super Iridiums, and the Astra SPs. My normal shaving process is WTG, XTG, ATG (3 passes total). The above 3 blades shaved smoothly and efficiently - There was never a need to go beyond 3 passes and sometimes only 2 passes were needed to obtain an exceptionally clean face. All 3 blades worked well in my Merkur 23C/180 and Parker 99R razors. The Feathers were just a tad sharper (more so when i used them in my 99R).<br /><br />In the end, I bought this 100 pack of Astras due to slightly longer durability and significantly better pricing. I have sparse but very coarse facial hair - Feathers give me 2-3 smooth shaves while I can get 3-4 (sometimes 5) smooth shaves with Iridiums/Astras. It is a no-brainer when you factor in that Astras are $9 for 100 blades compared to $30 (Feathers) and $35 (Iridiums) for the same blade count.<br /><br />With regards to packaging, the Astras blades are individually wrapped in a paper held together by a very small amount of wax. I have never taken the time to wipe off this wax as my shaving has never been negatively impacted.<br /><br />Overall, I am very happy with Astra SP blades. It's a double-bonus when high-performance comes at a very inexpensive price.
  1407. I started using a safety razor about 6 months ago coming from disposable blades. This is the second brand I've tried. The first one being the Derby Extra sample blades that came with the razor. I've used 3 Astra blades and so far I'm not impressed. One thing I've noticed in general about using a safety razor is that there is little to no irritation compared to disposables, they last longer and are easier to clean. Also, it is a lot cheaper to shave with safety razors, in the long run, compared to disposable blades.<br /><br />But not all blades will give a good shave to everyone. Comparing this two brands I noticed immediately that this brand nicks my skin a lot more than the Derby Extras and the disposable ones. The nicks are small, I don't feel when I get nicked and heal quickly with little bleeding but it's annoying. They do, however, stay sharp longer than the Derby Extras. I use a good shaving cream, a brush and even tried pre-shaving oils with no difference.<br /><br />These blades might work well for others but not for me. I may try a different brand or go back to the Derby Extra. Like others have said, the best option is to buy samples before committing to one brand.

  1412. I have recently switched to the old time flat double edge razor. I really wanted to go with a straight razor, but have to say that I am a little worried about silting my own throat. So my wife bought me a very nice Italian made safety razor where you unscrew the handle and place the flat double edge blades in the head. I LOVE IT!!! I have no idea how in the world we have been convinced by advertising to use commercialized razors and shave creams and gels that don’t last, give you razor burn and “shave bumps”. My face and neck has never been as happy as it is now. I don’t have razor burn any more and I actually enjoy shaving. Not to mention how cheap I can shave for compared to the so called modern ways.<br />My razor came with one or two blades and I used them while trying to make a decision on which blade to use long term. I know I should have bought one of the sample blade packs first, but after reading enough reviews and comparing prices, I chose the Astra blade. It appeared to have the best reviews for the price. I did not want to find a blade I really loved, just to be triple the price and feel guilty for buying it and then if I didn’t buy it fell like I settled for less. I know how my mind works. Astra seems to work very well for me. I shave three to four times a week (even though I need to shave every day, but like to give my skin a rest) and change out my blade every Sunday morning even though the blade still feels sharp and is doing a great job. At this price, even the cheapest of cheapskates (which I am) can enjoy the luxury of a new blade every week. I use Proraso Shave Soap and a boar’s hair brush. I know the different shave soaps will make a huge difference on the closeness of the shave as well. I am very happy with Astra blades and will more than likely stick with them. The packaging is great and with 100 blades for a few bucks, it means that I now have enough blades to last me just about 2 years for less than one of those high dollar commercialized disposable razors cost, that you use until you face is bleeding, just to justify the cost. I love it and wish I would have made this switch a long time ago.

These blades are very forgiving if your technique isn't great yet and won't nick you like the Feathers or other super sharp blades. I get a BBS shave with 3 passes easily and very little if any irritation! You can't beat the price and quality! The shipping was fast and right on time.
