  1417. Last follow up: I moved out of the last place I was living at and I have notice a remarkable difference in my shaving experience... and after a few months I have decided to be fair and ad a last update to my very poor feedback. It seems that I was experiencing a great deal of allergy at the last place I was living at and it directly affected my shaving: These blades may be made out of a Nickel-steel alloy (or another allergenic steel alloy) Hence, whenever I shaved they irritated my skin in a gruesome way generating a multitude of burns and cuts... since i moved out, now my shaving experience has improved dramatically. The blades are not top of the line, but they feel way better. So, if you suffer from allergies don't buy these blades. Nevertheless, if you are cleared of allergies these blades may be the best value around, you can shave safely around 4-6 times with each blade if you have sensitive skin and you are hairy. Skin damage is minimum and a close shave can be achieved more or less. Personally, I won't buy them again simply because of the allergic reactions described before, but otherwise they are a very good buy. I placed this last update on top just in case you are not up to reading my whole experience with these blades for the past year or so using them. But if you have the time and are interested about knowing what happens when you allergies and use these blades, you can read my earlier posts below. -------------------------------------------------- I am a hairy person who needs shaving daily. When I was a youngster living in Cuba in the late 80s I had to shave everyday, and I hated it... I always managed to cut my face all over... I used these very brand when it was produced in Czechoslovakia. later on I migrated and started using razors with cartridges that were better but more expensive. Now I decided to save some money and return to the origines in hope that this time the experience had been different... I was wrong: I still hate it... and manage to cut my face all over... the part I hate the most is when I manage to cut myself yet for some god-knows-what-reason there is still hair around and have to pass the razor over the damage area yet a few more times... I will try a different brand, maybe that will help... ------------------------------------------ This is a follow up: my face still hurts from yesterday's razor burns and I have to shave again... I guess using a blade more than once is effectively out of the question, and I am wondering how comes this product has so many good reviews... this blades are worst than the original ones I used in the 80s that were branded just &#34;Astra&#34;... now they improved greatly the name adding &#34;superior premium platinum...&#34; I guess to compensate for the huge loss in quality... I read in the web that Gillette bought that factory when Eastern Europe collapsed and moved it to Russia where it seems to be now... problem is that in the 80s in Cuba if you were lucky you could buy some Astras if not you had to buy Russian blades that the people used to say jokingly that were good only to sharpen pencils... so, I guess Russian manufacturing quality has not improved at all... by the way, I thought that first blade I used was the worst blade ever... but after using this second one I have to reckon I was mistaken. Those guys with great reviews talking about these blades are good and can be used 2 or 3 times each must have the face made of stone... ------------------------------------------- This is another follow up: I tried to easy the shaving experience adding baby oil and cocoa butter to see if the blade somehow slipped on my face and didn't end up with so much skin irritation, burns, and cuts... I failed miserably. The results remain stubbornly in place. I took a picture in an attempt to show how bad this experience is, but sadly there is no option to add pictures to a review. The main problem with these &#34;razors&#34; is that they are just way too dull. You have to pass more than 10 times over the same spot, thus producing a great deal of skin damage in the process and this is not to get a close shave... with these razors you can confidently forget about having a close shave. After burning and cutting my face all over my face still looks dark from the facial hair and feels like sandpaper... ------------------------------------------- This is another follow up for the gentlemen who left comments and advices regarding how to improve my shaving experience: I have just shaved with Feather razors... there is not even a difference, it is like if we are talking about two completely different things... so,it is definitely the blades: These Astra blades are no good... I have also realized that I could improve my shaving experience if I buy a better handle, better brush, and better cream... My advice: steer away from these razor blades and pay a little more for better ones... ------------------------------------------- Follow up: I have been shaving with the same Feather blade for the past 3 weeks, and I am starting to wonder if this blade was made to last forever... these blades may costs more, but at the end of the day you will have a way better experience, they will last way longer, and you will end up saving far more money and aggravation...

  1426. I took a chance and ordered the 100-pack right after I got my DE razor. I know that I probably should have started with a sampler, but oh well. Anyway, after about 8 months of wet shaving with a DE razor, I have used Astra SP, Shark Super Chrome, Derby, and Feather. The Astra SP's are my favorite of the bunch- which is a good thing, considering I have so many of them! I also like the Feathers; although I don't notice a difference in how my face feels afterword as opposed to the Astras. The main reason(s) why Feather is not my #1 choice is that they are more expensive, and I can only get two good shaves out of them before needing a new blade. The Astras leave my face silky smooth, and I can typically get 4-6 good shaves out a blade, before needing replacement. The overall value of the Astra SP's is hands-down the best of the bunch. I get zero tugging or pulling, no irritation, and a close, comfortable shave. What more could you ask for?<br /><br />Disclaimer: As with most shaving products, this is a YMMV thing. But for me, the Astras do the job, and they do it very well!
  1427. I have recently returned to double edge shaving after years of overpaying for cartridges. I became tired of paying so much and filling the landfill with the cartridges, and returned to double edge shaving. The Astra blades work great, and the price is outstanding.
  1428. My next favorite of DE blades. This would be my first choice if the Japanese Feather blades were not available. Very close shaves with all razors I own.
  1429. Great deal for safety razors. Saves a lot on money if you want to give it a try.
  1430. I've been a DE shaver for just over a year. The only other razor I've used is the Wilkinson Sword brand. Based on the high ratings of this blade, I went ahead and ordered the 100 Astra blades and am glad I did. I believe they are sharper than the Wilkinson's and last longer. A very smooth, comfortable shave.
  1431. 4/5 Stars because the blades have a slight inconsistency with them. Its packaged as a box with smaller boxes in it, and in those are the indiviual blades in waxed paper. I love this packaging. The issue is the blades themselves, such as 1/4 blades will be not as sharp and will cause unnecessary pull, cuts, burns that I don't get with the rest of the blades.
  1432. I am using a pack of these and wish I listened to people and tried the demos before I got a huge pack.<br />Astras are well known for being incredibly sharp, and I now know it for myself. I have dry skin around my mouth, so I really have to be careful shaving with these blades. But for cutting sideburns, they go through them like a hot blade through butter.<br /><br />I would suggest people try out demo packs before investing in a single type of blade. But if you are looking for a sharp blade, these are the ones.
  1433. Really great sharp blades. Shaves Really close but be careful when applying any pressure downwards on razor. They really are extremely sharp durable blades. Worth more than asking price. One box of 100 should last someone a long time.
  1434. I have been DE shaving for 3 years now and really got into it as a college student looking for a cheaper alternative to the expensive cartridge razors. I am currently purchasing my 2nd set of 100 Astra SP blades, almost exactly 2 years after my first box, so that gives you an idea of how long they last/how often I shave. I usually try to switch blades every 3 to 4 shaves, but I have razors that I use for travel and/or keep at home and school, so I'm sure I've gone many more than 4 shaves on some blades without knowing it. Probably less than 5 times have I ever actually noticed that a blade was getting dull and pulling hairs a little, so you could probably carry most blades out to 4+ shaves if you really felt like it, but a $10 investment for 2+ years (still have a few left) isn't too bad, even for me. In conclusion, these blades are well worth the money, but as anyone from B&B knows, your mileage may vary. Everyone's face reacts differently to certain blades and every blade acts different in each razor. I list the razors I commonly use these blades with below, in addition to other blades I have tried. Take all this for what you paid, as it is just my own unbiased experiences.<br /><br />Razors I use with Astra SP blades:<br />Gillette Tech (WW2 era), Gillette Travel Tech, Gillette Ball-End Tech, 1954 Gillette Super Speed, $2 Rimei razor (off Amazon, great razor for the money IMHO) and I have used a Gillette Slim Adjustable with these blades, though it wasn't mine.<br /><br />The only other blade I currently stock for myself is Derby blades. They are definitely not as sharp as Astra SP blades, but that is why I have them. I use them in a Dovo Shavette just because every now and then I like to practice my straight razor technique. The reason I use Derby blades for this is because honestly the Astra SP's were too sharp (and my technique sucks), so there was blood. The Derby blades are much more forgiving when using a straight. Don't take this to mean that the Astra's aren't good for beginners, because they are an outstanding beginner blade in a safety razor, just not for a straight...but I don't think a \\"beginner\\" straight razor truly exists.<br /><br />Other blades I've used: (In order of how they compare to Astra SP)<br /><br />Astra SS<br />http://amzn.com/B002G2VENC<br />Felt the same as Astra SP to me, but are always $4-$5 more, so I don't see the point...good blades though.<br /><br />Feather Hi-Stainless<br />http://amzn.com/B004RWTQTS<br />Extremely sharp (maybe slightly more than Astra SP), but not as smooth and left a very tiny amount of burn after the shave. Even in my Gillette Ball-End Tech (very mild) these had a little too much \\"bite\\" for me, but a ton of people love them. Honestly, cost was probably a huge factor in trying to find something wrong with these blades, but I really do prefer the Astra blades, regardless of cost.<br /><br />Derby<br />http://amzn.com/B004SGKMA0<br />These are not the sharpest blades out there, but they are usually the cheapest. If you are looking for an acceptable shave at the cheapest cost, this is the obvious choice. In my opinion though, you are going to save less than $1 per 100 in comparison to Astra SP blades. If you are like me and a box lasts you 2+ years, then you've saved yourself about 1 cent a week, so you might as well have the best experience you can and go for Astra. I actually use these in my straight, mentioned above, so I don't have a problem with these blades, but there is no comparison in terms of sharpness to Astra SP, Astra SS or especially Feather blades. I just prefer a little more sharpness in my safety razor, because I think it translates to a few less passes and slightly less of the hair pulling sensation. Please note, most of my razors are widely considered fairly mild shavers, so the Derby blades might be better in a more aggressive razor, many of which can be found on Amazon in the $30 range.<br /><br />Personna<br />http://amzn.com/B0077LAJT2<br />These blades were fairly sharp and smooth, rivaling the Astra SP, but I had some inconsistency issues with them. I had 25 of these blades that I received from a friend in a trade for Astra's and it seemed like 10/25 were much rougher than the rest. It felt like there was a small bur on the blade that I could feel as I shaved. It wasn't a horrible sensation, I could just feel that something was rubbing in a tiny little area, though I couldn't see any blade imperfections. I know it was the blade edge, because if I flipped the razor over to the other side, it felt fine. This happened on a few different razors. Eventually I started using these in my Dovo shavette because I could break off the half of the blade that caused the problem. This experience may have just been a weird batch and I'm sure it isn't a common thing, at least I hope not, but it was enough to turn me off. For what it's worth, I have heard that there is a medical quality version of this blade that is very highly rated, though I don't think it is available on Amazon (they need to fix that!), so they might be worth finding some day.<br /><br />Wilkinson Sword<br />http://amzn.com/B000GCSFWW<br />Honestly my least favorite blade that I've tried, these came with my Dovo Shavette (I think). They seem to have about the same sharpness as a Derby blade, but they didn't feel smooth at all. It was like I could feel and hear the blade cutting through each individual hair. I used the 5 that I had (at least 2 in my safety razors) and never considered them again. These are the only blades on this list that I actually recommend avoiding, but once again, that is just my opinion.<br /><br />Background Info (for the few that made it this far):<br />I have a coarse beard and shave 2-3 times a week usually. I try to always shave after taking a shower, but sometimes in a rush I just shave in the shower using only the water and I've never had any problems. When I'm not rushed, I use Van der Hagen Deluxe shave soap, which is definitely on the cheap end, but I don't have any problem with it whatsoever! It has a very mild soap scent, which I like because I would rather smell like my cologne then my shaving soap...just my personal preference. I have tried the red and the white Proraso soaps available on Amazon. They were great, but you just can't beat the <$2 price of the Van der Hagen.<br /><br />I hope this was helpful! I'm sure a ton of veteran shavers agree and disagree with what I've said, but this is my fairly unbiased opinion of the products I've tried. Everyone's face is different, but when I give a gift to a friend who becomes interested after seeing my vintage razors (definite cool factor shaving with a 70+ year old piece of equipment), you don't want to spend a ton on something when there's a good chance they may not take to the hobby, yes shaving can become a hobby. The beginner kit I build usually includes:<br /><br />Astra SP blades (usually a 5 pack is enough to see if someone is gonna stick with it)<br /><br />Van der Hagen Shave Set (includes the soap I use, as well as a bowl and brush)<br />http://amzn.com/B001A3HPT0<br /><br />Rimei $2 Razor (listed as Rosalinni, but you'll get a Rimei usually)<br />http://amzn.com/B0050HO9MI<br />Great beginner razor, comparable to Gillette Tech. The build quality is pretty good, but I know there are at least 3 different versions of the Rimei going around. One is a 4-piece, while the other two are 3-piece razors. I have never encountered the 4-piece, but both 3-piece razors are good. If you can figure out which one a seller offers, try to get the 3-piece with cross-hatching on the handle, as opposed to the one with a mainly vertical-lined handle, because it has a better finish and grip.<br /><br />I hope all this was helpful!

  1471. Ignore the Dollar Shave Club. Cry foul on the lies perpetuated by Gillette and Schick. Buy yourself an old-school safety razor and a box of these blades and you're set for the next year (or more, if you're like me and just use the razor to shape up a full beard). Not only do they shave more comfortably and precisely, but they're more durable and a hell of a lot cheaper. So keep your silly nano blades with useless lubrication strips and array of 5 laser aligned $16 razors. Instead, follow these easy steps:<br /><br />1) Put razor blade on safety razor<br />2) Wet face with as hot water (or hot towel) as you can stand, ideally immediately after a shower to soften the whiskers and open pores<br />3) Apply the pre-shave oil of your choice<br />4) Apply the shaving cream of your choice (ideally with a shaving brush used in a circular motion to get those whiskers standing tall and proud)<br />5) Make with the shaving<br />6) Rinse<br />7) Apply post shave product of your choice - preferably something that stinks all pretty like<br />8) Rejoice in your new shaving ritual that not only shaves better, but also more cheaply, than ever before

  1476. Astra Superior Platinums are widely regarded among the internet shaving forums as a very well rounded, great performing blade. It's not the best in any single category, but it's darn good in all categories. Coupled with the price (around 10 cents a blade regularly here on amazon), the Astra SP is the go-to blade for a huge population of wet shavers. To put it into perspective....the ultra-sharp and ultra-aggressive feather blade favored by a lot of experienced users goes for about 30 cents a blade (on a good day)....and they last about half as long as an Astra SP. They may be sharper, but the Astra SP is sharp enough.<br /><br />Pro tip- The Astras are packaged with 4 little wax spots on one side of the blade to secure it to the wrapper. What I usually do if the wax has overflown onto the blade edge itself is to install the blade in the razor, then run it under the hottest water possible to melt the wax. What doesn't melt can be wiped off by running the razor in reverse over a towel (BE VERY CAREFUL - DO NOT ATTEMPT IF YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT I'M TALKING ABOUT. YOU WILL HURT YOURSELF AND WE WILL ALL LAUGH).
  1477. They were as advertised and came in a timely manner
  1478. Updated 2016 I had to update my review from a few years ago. After trying several other brands, I keep coming back to the Astra. I can confidently say these are the best blades I have found. I must admit it did take a few weeks to adjust to shaving with a safety razor and a new blade but please save your money and don't waste it by trying another brands. Shaving is like art, it takes patience and you will develop your own style and technique. My biggest advice when using these blades, is 1. Use as little pressure as possible. 2. Rinse the blade after every stroke. Original Review. I recently tried the Astra superior premium blades after using the Derby blades for a few months. At first I was very impressed in how smooth a shave you get with these blades. To be honest, you really can't even tell you have a blade in your shaver. However, feeling my skin after the shave I can tell it wasn't as close a shave as the Derby blades. In fact, I noticed I had more irritation and bleeding compared to the Derby blades when everything else is kept the same (preshave oil, preshave lotion etc..). For the price you can't go wrong to try them as everyone's skin type is different; However, another drawback even though small is that each blade is packaged separately with paper and you have no container to place the used blades. That might be a safety issue if you have children or even emptying trash unlike the Derby brand that come in a plastic container for easy disposal of used blades.

  1522. If you use a safety razor, get these! Unbelievably sharp resulting in an incredibly close and amazing shave. Since I have a beard and only shave to neaten up and keep lines clean these will last me for a substantial amount of time, and could not believe the price!

  1524. I've been using these for the better part of a year now on a Parker 91R and I really like them. Flipping the blade after each shave I would say I get about 6 really high quality shaves out of one of these blades, though my hair is not super dense. After 6 I generally switch to avoid scratches and rashes from dull blades. The only downside preventing 5 stars is that the packaging of each individual blade includes some glue that interferes with one edge of the blade on maybe 1 out of 10 blades.
  1525. I have been using various Schick and Gillette cartridge products for over 20 years and decided I want to try something different now. I bought a full kit for DE shaving - [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]], [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]], [[ASIN:B001JHEY14 Proraso Shave Soap, Sensitive, 150ml/5.2 oz (147 g) Jar]] and finally, [[ASIN:B001QY8QXM 100 Astra Superior Premium Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades]].<br /><br />I used the blade that came with the razor for about 8 shaves and then switched to the Astra. As another reviewer has pointed out, there is a bit of glue residue at times while opening the blade wrapper. But this normally doesn't affect the edge as much. My experience so far after using 4 blades has been a bit underwhelming. The shave isn't as smooth as the one with the original Merkur blade and I barely get about 4-5 shaves. I have been consistent with the method so that other factors are eliminated or minimized.<br /><br />So while disappointed with the shave quality, I am still rating this at 4-stars mainly for the price. This is definitely a huge value for the money but I will probably try other brands before coming back to Astra in the future.
  1526. This product works well for scoring bread and holds a sharp edge, however it has 2 sticky spots when you peel the protective paper off.
  1527. I've been through more than a dozen DE blade brands, and Astra is emerging as my favorite. While others may advertise as sharper or smoother, I have yet to find a blade that delivers the performance, value, and comfort that Astra does. I'm currently using it with a Dreadnought Spartan Razor, and the combination of the two is giving me excellent-to-flawless shaves every time, without going over the same spots too many times (although I do follow the WTG/XTG/ATG plus touch-up beard reduction routine).<br /><br />In terms of longevity, at pennies per blade, I don't feel too bad about using each three times and discarding - particularly with my tough-as-nails beard. But I am fairly confident I could get more shaves out of each blade if I really needed to. Others have advertised longer blade life, so as we all like to say (ad nauseum), \\"your mileage may vary.\\"<br /><br />I strongly believe this is a forgiving enough blade for beginners but will also reward the long-time shaver who can get close shaves with an aggressive razor.
  1528. Bought these off the recommendation of the Wicked Edge community on Reddit. Glad that I did, they are extremely sharp and well packaged. Each blade is individually wrapped to ensure a good edge and so that they won't rust on the shelf in a steamy bathroom. Here are my initial impressions after four shaves:<br /><br />Pro:<br />- Good shave; comparable to the Feather<br />- The heft of the blade seems to shave better with the grain<br />- .10 per blade is a great deal<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The heft of the razor seemed to nick me a little more against the grain.<br /><br />All said, this is my new blade of choice.   1531. I've used about 75% of the blades so I thought it was time for a review, so far I've only tried Feather and Derby double edge razor blades. The Feather blades are, as you may all know the most praised when it comes to how sharp they are, they are indeed very very sharp but a tad bit rough from my experience. The Astra blades are not as sharp as the Feather but are much smoother, they give an excellent shave, I actually prefer them to the Feather blades since they're cheaper. One thing that may bother some people is that the blades have glue dots on them, although I have found that it doesn't diminish the quality of the shave in any way some people might find this irritating. Still, given the value and excellent performance of the blades I won't knock down a star for that tiny issue. The durability is normal, I shave every two days or so but I immediately notice they become less smooth after about the second or third shave, but you do get 100 so you're supposed to change them often.<br /><br />As for the Derby blades, I tried the ones that came with my Edwin Jagger 89lbl and they sucked so much that I ended up given most of them to a friend, which also hated them and I felt bad so I gave him some Astra blades to try and he loved them.

I am a total fan and hope others take advantage of this great option and leave the supposedly superior blades to others.

  1559. Like other reviewers I have become increasingly frustrated with the decreasing low-quality shave of multi-blade razors. I spent 6 months trying every single multi-blade razor. These razors remove the shaving cream before eliminating the hair tips. They leave a frustrating choice between pushing the blades against the bare skin, and getting a rash, or keeping a sandpaper face. I decided to try a third choice: return to safety razor, after over 30 years of plastics, and was very pleasantly surprised.<br /><br />The Astra blades are terrific. They leave my face smooth after 1-2 passes. I did not have any cuts, bruises or scratches, for several months, since I switched to safety razor. The Atra blades can last for 3-5 shaves, but they are priced so low that you can change the blade with every shave.<br /><br />As for mulit-blade razors. Razor companies make more money by increasing the number of blades, to max price, while reducing their sharpness, to minimize. It is only a matter of time before we see a 10-blade razor that can barely remove the shaving cream.

  1586. You will love me, and my father for what he taught me regarding double edged safety razor blades.<br /><br />To get a GREAT SHAVE with a safety razor and NOT CUT YOURSELF. You must put in TWO(2) razor blades inside of your razor. This will give you double the strength so it won't cut you. If you only use one razor blade, its so thin, and it bends so easily, that it will cut you like a paper cut. So thin, ZIP, you're cut.<br /><br />The strength of the two(2) blades will keep it strong and you can wiggle your razor blade up, down, left, right, fast, slow. Its much easier than ANY disposable razor blade. It even lasts longer than any disposable razor blade.<br /><br />So if this helps you...and you find it helpful that you end up using a razor blade and stay using razor blades and double edged razor blades. Thank, Bing C. Dionida, me..LOL. Really thank my father for sharing this with me SO LONG AGO. I can't believe NO ONE has pointed this out before. Thank You, DAD Bing I. Dionida for sharing this secret. Though he uses an electric shaver now...LOL.

I have a very rough beard (I shave everyday in the morning after I shower) so it wasn't surprising I wasn't able to use Safety Razors. I was, however, hoping to save some money by going this route over the Mach3. I also have an Phillips Norelco SensoTouch 3D electric razor which works okay if I use it everyday (anything past 2 days it won't work) though, I still have to use my Mach3 afterwards to get a close, most of the day worth, clean shave. These blades (Astra) cut me in 4 or 5 spots almost every time I've tried using them. I thought it was because I needed more practice but, after a few days of getting cut, waiting till they healed and then getting cut again I decided this just wasn't going to happen. The Mach3 has never cut me even once after years of using them. Cheap disposable plastic razors cut me too; just like these Astras did.<br /><br />With that said, I think it's me in this case so, I feel slightly bad about giving these blades a poor rating but, I really don't like them so, that is my personal honest review. I know it's probably not fair under this context but, it is what it is.<br /><br />If you have a fairly normal beard then I'm sure you'll be fine with these. If you don't have issues with Safety Razors then you'll probably be fine with these. If you can get a clean shave from an electric razor in the first try then I'm sure these will be fine for you. They definitely have allot of positive reviews. If, however, you're more like me and are a bear of man when it comes to your beard and arethinking about switching to Safety Razors and these Astra blades than be prepared to have possible issues. I sure did!<br /><br />I'm considering trying some other blades and or upgrading my Merkur. If and when I do I will update this review. This should determine if a third type of blade is better and doesn't cut me or if it's the Safety Razor itself that was the issue etc.
  1600. Double edge blades not available at retail stores any longer. These seem a little thinner than the last I purchased at drugstore but are satisfactory for the side burn trimming that they are used for.

  1612. Bought them back in March 2014 and I still have about one half of the box to go ( Due to my employer I have to shave everyday I work). They fit my Merkur safety razor and give a close shave. If you pay attention to the blade you will notice it is numbered on each side (1 and 2 on one side/ 3 and 4 on the other). It seems to be sharper on the side numbered with 1 and 2 (it may differ for you, I have extremely thick beard) and I can shave up to four times with it.<br />This is the only brand I have tried so far and it works well for me. There could possibly be other brands that would be of better quality out there (and more expensive). This seems to work for me because I got tired of throwing my money away (usually 25 bucks monthly) on a disposable cartridge that would give me a low quality shave.
  1613. Bought my first safety razor and it came with 2 feather blades. After the first time and first stroke with a feather blade I didn't think I had pressed hard enough because I didn't feel any pulling or tugging and didn't think it had done anything but it had done a fantastic very close smooth cut. I used the feathers 5 times each (the product came with 2). I read great reviews on the Astra Platinum and decided to go with them thinking there couldn't be much difference between blade brands and the priced seemed good. That assumption was a big mistake. The two used feather blades I had tossed had been far sharper after 5 shaves than a brand new Astra while the Astra pulled and tugged noisily as if it was a very old used blade. Not happy about it especially considering I got 100 of them. A brand new Astra Platinum blade shave needs touch up after the shave (I shave in the shower and have average beard growth).

  1623. I got into wet shaving back in 2011 when my girlfriend got me a Parker SR-1 for my birthday (which I still use today), and I've subsequently tried all sorts of razor blades. I started with Shark, and they were okay, but they didn't provide the smoothest shave. They were okay for a light shave, but close shaves with them were uncomfortable at best and agonizing at worst. So I moved on and tried some others. Tried Merkur, Derby, Shark Super Chrome, etc., etc. with less than stellar results. I also tried Feather and liked the shave, but the expense sent me searching for something else.<br /><br />Finally, I found my way to Astra Superior Premium Platinum. I wasn't expecting much given the price, but they wound up being exactly what I had been searching for all along. They give me an extremely smooth, close shave with little to no irritation. I have a very coarse beard that grows very quickly, and these Astra blades make quick work of it. As a plus, they are extremely affordable. I greatly appreciate this, as I have to shave daily and I rarely get more than two shaves out of a single blade due to the coarseness of my facial hair.<br /><br />In summary, these blades wound up being perfect for me. They might not suit you, but I would highly recommend giving them a try. They're high quality, consistently sharp and very affordable. Excellent.
  1624. I am a new convert to DE shaving, and everyone kept telling me to get a sampler pack. I guess I could have, but I am in academics and ultimately like homework, so I did my homework. I purchased an Edwin Jagger DE 89 for my first DE razor and chose these Astra blades as its compliment. I have a heavy thick beard and knew that I would need something on the sharper end of the spectrum, but not the Feather-level of sharp. So, I chose these Astra blades and couldn't be happier with the outcome.<br /><br />For me, I use TOBS Jermyn Street Sensitive Skin shaving cream, the Edwin Jagger, and these Astra blades, and have a great shave every time. I have been getting about 4 shaves with these, but I have to say, I wait a good 3-4 days between shaves, so it's pretty heavy by the time I shave. Even with heavy growth and a thick beard, these, in conjunction with the Edwin Jagger have had no problem, and I continue to get the best shave of my life. As a new convert to DE razors and real shaving cream, I have to say that if you've considered the switch, but are hesitant, do your homework, get good products, and you won't be sorry, I'm not.

The shave these blades give is fantastic. I have a medium to heavy beard and am getting 4 to 5 shaves per blade (your mileage may vary) so do the math, that's at least a year of shaving for $10.95. Besides the great shaves, what I like the best is shaving with an absolutely clean razor every time. I never could get all the gunk from between the blades on the multi-blade razors. I break down my Gillette and completely rinse the head and the blade and have a pristine razor for my next shave.<br /><br />If you are already rockin' it old school or want to start, I highly recommend the Astra blades.

  1655. Packaging is convenient, with 5 blades individually wrapped in wax paper in a small cardboard box - 20 of which fit into the box which can be used as a dispenser.<br /><br />My favorite part, though, is that I have exactly zero (0) qualms with using a blade 2-3 times before disposing of it. In the past, I'd stretch blades up to 10 uses. Don't get me wrong, I've used the blades about five times before replacing them. They maintain a good edge, and I have very coarse, thick facial hair. However, it's still a small luxury to use them only when they're ultimately sharp within the first 3 uses.<br /><br />These will be my go-to blades from now on.

  1696. I recently made the switch to a safety razor (the Merkur classic safety razor) and picked up a box of these Astra blades after using the included Merkur blade. For me the Astra blades do a slightly better job than Merkur blade and for 9 cents a pop you can't really go wrong.<br /><br />The shave that the blade provided was clean and quick. It was plenty sharp and I didn't have any nicks, cuts, or any razor burn from the blade at all. Overall the Astra blades provided a great, clean, and close shave. I was very impressed.<br /><br />I know there are other packages of 100 mixed brand blades out there for 2 - 3x the price where you can get a feel for and find the exact right blade for you face but I'm not that picky, so finding the cheapest option was high on my priority list. These were the cheapest blades I could find.<br /><br />All I can say is that I'm never going back to disposable razors again and as long as the Astra blades remain cheap, I'm sticking with them.
  1697. I tried out a sample pack of razors before going with these. They were one of my favorites of the sample pack, and the cheapest per dollar by far. I've been using them for a few months now and have 0 complaints.
  1698. I know everyone raves about feather razor blades. I will admit they are very sharp. I personally don't like a blade as sharp as a feather because of using a more aggressive shaving razor. Astra's have given me great smooth shaves and at around $9 per 100 pack they are hard to beat on the pricing. I recommend giving one of this packs a try. If for some reason you don't like them, which is probably highly unlikely, you will only be out the price of a burger basket.
  1699. If I want a very smooth shave from a new blade, Astra SP is the blade I load in my razor. I only get about three good shaves before they start tugging a bit, but at less than 10 cents a blade, I can't complain. If you haven't tried Astra's, you should.
  1700. Great quality, no complaints.
  1701. I shave my head along with my face and I've tried a lot of the variety packs and that means a lot of different blades. I settled on a few favorites and over time I've found that by far ASTRA gives me the closest shave and one of the most consistent blades I've found. Safety razors are highly personal, meaning we all have our preferences and there isn't by any means a 'one size fits all'.<br /><br />Compared to Compared to MERKUR - ASTRA is just a better value. Compared to FEATHER - ASTRA matches the sharpness but is more forgiving. Feather was so sharp that I'd more frequently than I'd like to admit cut myself. Compared to SHARK - ASTRA is way more consistent blade to blade. At this point there isn't another blade for me, I'll stick with ASTRA.
  1702. TONS OF RAZOR BLADES. Unbeatable for the price. Razors come in packs of five, so this will last a while. I would recommend this.
  1703. Again, like many have said, no one razor blade will work for everyone. It's best to buy a sampler pack and base your decision off of that.<br /><br />When I got my Merkur 180 it came with Merkur blades. Those felt like shaving with a piece of broken glass so I purchased a sampler pack. Most of them gave the same experience except for 3 - the Astras, Derbys, and Feathers. The Derby blades were good but gave some razor burn, the Feathers were overkill, but the Astra blades were perfect and I kept going back to those.<br /><br />If you decide that Astra blades are right for your face then you really can't beat this combo - at 10 blades for $1 it's a steal. They last about 3 or 4 shaves, so since I shave every other day this box should last me 2 years no problem.

  1706. Great razors but seem to dull mid shave. I find that I get about two great shaves, one mediocre shave, and one half mediocre- half butcher job out of one razor. At least I'm getting two great shaves out of each blade, which is better than I can say for other brands of blades I have tried.

  1718. Sharp, smooth, pennies per shave. That is the best way that I can summarize Astra Superior Platinum blades.<br /><br />Astra SP work well for me in my Edwin Jagger DE89, Gillette NEW, Super Speed, and Adjustable. In other words, they work well in everything that I put them in.<br /><br />I've tried a large number of different blades and some are sharper and many are duller than Astra. Gillette Silver Blue seems a touch sharper and is still smooth. Astra easily beats it in terms of value. I actually haven't found any blades that beat Astra for sharpness and smoothness for the money.<br /><br />These are not the blade of choice for everyone. No double edge blade is. They seem to work well for most, with only a relatively small number of people disliking them as evidenced by the wet shaving forums.
  1719. I really like these blades. I'm new to the whole safety blade trend. These blades work wonders for me. The thing to remember with all safety blades is that they are meant to be changed regularly. They don't last as long as other blades but I find that they provide a superior cut. Finding the right pressure for your skin is critical. I have very sensitive skin, so for me I need to change the blades after every 2 to 3 shaves. It can take some practice but once you have it down, these blades are excellent.
  1720. i have never been able to shave everyday of the week no matter what type of razor that was used. I have been wet shaving for the past year and came across these beauties and now my face is as smooth as a baby's bottom. Astra blades are the best ever bar none
  1721. I'm new to DE shaving, and the only blade I've used other than the Astra SP is the Merkur blade that came with my Merkur Long Handle razor. I bought this pack of 100 before I found out about the sampler packs, and was worried I might have jumped the gun. But, luckily, these blades have never given me any problems. No irritation or shaving bumps, and my face is smooth as glass after a second, against-the-grain pass. The only gripe I have, and the reason these blades get a 4/5, is because of the glue noted by other reviewers. The third blade I used had glue all over the edge, and while it was pretty easily removed with hot tap water and a thick towel (BE CAREFUL!), it's not something I want to do regularly.
  1722. I've been wet shaving for 3 or 4 years now and moved from a cartridge razor to a safety razor almost 2 years ago. Astra Superior Platinum blades have become my normal daily shaver. I own a Merkur 38C (my travel razor), a 1951 Gillette Super Speed Black Tip (my daily driver) and a 1961 Gillette Slim Adjustable (when I want an extra close shave). I have sensitive skin and coarse facial hair.<br /><br />Like most everyone else, I bought an initial sampler with 60 blades and tried several of them. Once I worked out my technique, I re-sampled to see which blades I actually liked. I won't bother talking about the blades I just didn't care for.<br /><br />1. The Derby Extra was the first blade I liked. But it was only good for a couple of shaves before it had to be tossed out.<br />2. Then I discovered the Shark Super Chrome. It lasted longer and shaved pretty close. It was the first real winner.<br />3. When I tried the Astra Superior Platinum, I felt like I'd mastered my shaving technique and was ready for a sharper blade. I get no irritation. This was the blade I ended up sticking with. My last pack of 30 lasted about 7 months (shaving, on average, somewhere between daily and every other day). I finally ran out and have just ordered another 100.<br />4. Feathers. These Japanese blades are ridiculously sharp. They require a good feel for your razor and being comfortable with the contours of your face. They are not for beginners.<br /><br />Bottom line, the Astras are legitimately not as sharp as Feathers, but they are consistently great blades. I haven't run into any Quality Control issues with them. I get a super close shave with no irritation. And they stand up to multiple shaves.
  1723. very good quality!<br />easy to use and extremely sharp!<br />recommended for people who using safety razor!<br />its a great product

  1726. The platinum tipped Astra razors came new in the box. There are 20 smaller boxes containing 5 razors--each razor covered in protective paper. The \\"glue\\" that holds them in the paper is easily wiped off before you place it in the razor (those reports of it being hard to wipe off are totally unfounded in my opinion). In fact, the \\"glue\\" is more like a cream than glue.<br /><br />The razors themselves are spectacular. I had been using my previous razor too long and was shocked at how easy a shave I could get with a new, good quality razor. One swipe left my face almost completely clean.<br /><br />Overall, very good price for very good razors.

  1730. Update******** The ones purchased here on Amazon are not quality Astra blades. Could be counterfeit. They are individually package in white paper. Real ones are packaged in Astra print paper. Quality of shave is also not the same. I bought some here on Amazon and another 100 blades from another supplier and found the paper discrepancy and the quality of shave is not there. All packaging was identical for the exception of the individually wrapped blades paper and most importantly blade quality is different. I'll keep buying Astra blades but definitely not from here. Before you buy from anyone ask if it has the Astra print paper. If the answer is yes, then you have the real deal. Don't throw away your money to save 1 or 2 dollars. The below review is on authentic blades. Best razor for my skin. Leaves me no razor burn and cuts through my facial hair like butter. I've tried others like feather, merkur, shark and derby and this one is the best for me. Barely any nicks and no burn for my skin type. I tried this brand on a sampler and by far the best from the sampler package.
  1731. I'll try to keep this simple and to the point. I've tried several DE razors and currently have settled on two choices: Astra and Feathers. Astras perform well and are inexpensive especially when buying the 100 count carton/pack. You could use these blades 1-2 times and still come out ahead in savings compared to the cartridge type loading razors out there. There are many razors on the market but I suggest you give these blades a try because they work.   1803. Gillette built a state of the art plant in St<br />Petersburg, Russia, that consistently produces some of the world's finest DE blades. All products from there are top quality, my favorites are Astra Superior Platinum, Gillette Silver Blue, and Polsilver Super Iridium. The price for a 100 blade sleeve Astras is a steal. The Astra is very sharp but smooth, I get at least 7 baby butt smooth shaves per blade, and could very well get more. Razorwise, I alternate between a '56 Superspeed, and an Atlas R1, with the occasional fat handle Tech. The Astra is definitely my go to blade.
  1804. The Astra's are one of my favorite blades. They're sharp without being too sharp and very smooth. I do like a couple of other blades a little better, but the Astras are so much less expensive that I couldn't pass them up.
  1805. A great product for the $$$! Yes, it's cheap but worth the value.
  1806. Excellent price, excellent product in both quantity and quality.<br /><br />there is a slight sticky residue that is in each individually wrapped blade that seems odd. A good rinse is a good fix.
  1807. These are excellent and well worth the price (less than a dime a blade). If you are looking for bulk blades for your safety razor, I highly recommend these.
  1808. sweet price and great shave
  1809. Not what I expected, felt the Derby did a more aggressive shave. However, the Astra does have a smooth shave, but you will need to make multiple passes.
  1810. I use a combination of these Astra SP blades along with Feather blades (from Japan) in my Merkur 38c double edged safety razor. The Feathers are just a tiny, tiny bit sharper in my opinion but the Astras last about four or five shaves compared to the three shaves I can get from a Feather. That said, I purchased 100 of these blades for less than $10. (100 Feathers in the USA is usually about $27 to $34 on Amazon) Cant beat the price. Currently, I use the Astras as my weekday blades and Feathers for special evening or weekend functions. 4.9 stars out of five.
  1811. I switched over to a double edge safety razor 8 months ago from cartridge razors (mach 3s) and I couldn’t be happier. I read a whole lot about different types of blades and decided to try these out. I couldn’t be happier about the quality of shave, and ecstatic about the price.<br /><br />Before these, I have only used cartridge razors and disposables (mach 3, Bic, etc.) and compared to those the quality of shave I get from these blades is just excellent. I usually take 3 passes on my face, but don’t really need to. It’s perfectly smooth after two; the third is just for good measure. I use these to shave my face as well as my head, and they work fine for both. When I first started DE shaving I would shave every other day. At that rate each blade would last approx. 3 weeks. Lately, I’ve been shaving every two to three days, and each blade is lasting over a month. What I mean is that I would still get good shaves out of the blade for 3 weeks to a month, depending. The blades do get noticeably duller towards the 3 week mark and I am able to tell when it is time to replace it.<br /><br />I paid around $10 for pack of 100 premium blades. When comparing that to what I used to pay for cartridge razors it doesn’t get any better. I have read reviews about better or sharper blades. I’m sure there are plenty out there, but these do a great job for an even better price.
  1812. A great deal for the money. Smooth and consistent. There are better blades but this is one of the best values. Some people are put off with the small amount of wax used to hold the wrapping in place. Only a few drops that melt off under warm water but all the better to insure that you get a good blade when when the wrapper is removed.
  1813. Great blades and great value.<br /><br />When I tried this line of blades as part of a multi-pack this was one of just a few standout models. They aren't as sharp or agressive as the Japanese Feathers, but they just glide effortlessly over the face so I get less irritation and never cut myself. That means I can shave more frequently if needed.<br /><br />I can confirm the assertion in other reviews indicating that some glue residue is on every blade due to how they are packaged. It's a little annoying to rub them each off but by no means a deal breaker. Untouched the glue probably does not interfere, but just for peace of mind I rub it off quickly. No problem.<br /><br />In a couple of years when I run out I'll try another platinum blade. Until then though, I'm happy.

I have a medium beard thickness, so those of you with heavier beards may need to change yours out more often. These are great blades, well priced. One of these packages is almost sufficient for a year using two blades a week, an incredible value when you think about it. You can pretty much eliminate the cost of razors by using this product.<br /><br />I have used DE razors for 4-5 years now and have no regrets. Every time I see the incredibly expensive packs of cartridges for the latest Gillette razors at Costco I am amazed that so many people pay so much for a product that does not work as well as the 1904 technology in an original double edge safety razor.   1890. While I personally put more value in the quality of the shaving cream/soap being used, the blade itself is responsible for cutting the hair (and other things if not careful). There are a myriad of razor blade options available, but I wanted affordable quality and was fortunate enough to try ASTRA DOUBLE EDGE RAZOR BLADES from the start.<br /><br />I have been using these blades over 5 months and I have NEVER experienced shaves as close as I’ve been getting in those 5 months. Remarkably thin, yet durable, I can squeeze a week of daily shaves (moderate-to-heavy facial hair growth) from each blade before needing to replace it. The math definitely works in my favor as I can get almost an entire year of great, super close shaves from a single box of blades that costs less than one refill pack of the “high-end” disposable 5-blade garbage being peddled to the masses (they’re only good for a handful of shaves before needing to be replaced).<br /><br />I find the ASTRA DOUBLE EDGE RAZOR BLADES providing the quality I’m looking for at a price that can’t be beat.

  1895. I started my wet-shaving experience with a 10-pack of Feathers. Sharper is better, right?<br /><br />Not really. I thought all the cuts and burning were simply de rigeur for wet shaving. In the interest of full disclosure, I should say that I often experienced nicks around the corners of my mouth and around my throat using disposable razors like the Mach 3. So I'm probably at least partly at fault in terms of technique. However, that same technique resulted in zero cuts my very first time using one of my Astra blades. Amazing!<br /><br />But clearly there must have been a trade-off in terms of closeness of shave, right? NO! If anything, the quality of shave was even better with the Astra! I think that because the blade is less aggressive, I must have been able to give a little more attention to my problem areas.<br /><br />This is not to say that the Astras are unequivocally the best choice for everyone. I don't have particularly dense or coarse facial hair, and I image that a sharper blade like the Feather is extremely helpful for those who do in mowing down their facial forrest.

  1912. These are the lightest touch of a blade that has touched my face in 35 years. I never left DE blades. Shaved a couple of times with bic and other disposable multi-blade crud over the years, usually while away in the Military because at times we couldn't have DE type razors (like Basic, AIT, SERE school and a few other bizarre training cycles) always went back to my original Gillette butterfly (don't ask a model number cause they don't make them nor do I care to find what the model was since they haven't been made since before I was born - mine being 2 brand new hand-me down from a Grandfather who hoarded a few before they went off the market). Anyway, to get back on topic, I have used these in my Gilette, my Edwin Jagger De89bl Double Edge Safety Razor Chrome Plated, and some cheap Silver Tone Double Edge Blade Razor Shaver w Nonslip Metal Handle (that I travel with and it cost a WHOLE $3). These blades are PHENOMENAL. They cost a penny plus some 100ths of a cent each shave- seriously each blade is less than 10 cents. I get 7-10 shaves from a blade (PS the Military made me shave 2x a day, just about every day since my beard is so noticeable - not quite like Former Pres Nixon but darn close).   1914. I have been DE shaving now for a few months. I have tried Feather, Shark, Derby, Gillette, and Astra blades. Feather are too sharp, it seems hard to not nick yourself. Shark, Derby, and gilette blades seem to be dull and pull. Astra blades are perfect. I get a great shave without nicks. I get 4 shaves out of an Astra blade, so at 10 cents a blade ... 2.5 cents a shave ... great.
  1915. These blades are amazing. Review over.<br />Alright, longer version: I got a 52' Gillette Super Speed a few days ago, these fit perfectly. They are incredibly sharp, but have a small enough cutting surface so they are easy to hold without slicing yourself. Their packaging is very good, 20 boxes of 5 individually packaged blades. Each blade is in a bit of wax paper, in a paper envelope, then 5 envelopes in a small cardboard box, 20 small cardboard boxes in the full set.<br />There is one part that threw me a bit. The cut is incredibly smooth, and quiet (If you've used a straight edge razor, you'll know what I mean on the later) to the point of having a hard time telling if the blade is cutting, or just brushing hair, believe me: it is cutting.<br />I have heard that Feather blades are sharper, to the point of cutting flesh very easily. They are also far more expensive. Ie. 100 Feather blades are around $25, so roughly twice times as expensive as 100 Astras.<br /><br />Edit: I accidentally mistrusted the price on Feather razor blades as 37/100, when on taking another look it is only around 25/100
  1916. Very sharp blades. At this price, and quantity, you could use a couple a week and still go an entire year before you had to buy more... this is fantastic! They are very sharp!
  1917. They are ok, they dull faster in my opinion. I prefer derbys or personnas
  1918. These blades are ok. I get a reasonable shave with these but I think the derby blades are better & cost less. Blades of course depend upon you skin, beard, razor, shaving cream & other factors so you might like these more than I. I don't care for the drops of wax they put on the blades to attach the paper that they are wrapped in but it does not affect the shave.
  1919. I'm not sure why these blades are getting such rave reviews. I found that the ones I got do the job, but just barely. I based my purchase on the majority of good reviews here, and now I have a bunch of blades that I'm not too thrilled with.<br /><br />Anyhow, be advised that if you're considering buying these blades, in my experience they're not as good as the other reviews would lead you to believe.
  1920. You can not beat the price of this product. 100 razors for 10 bucks will keep you going for a long time to come. That being said, the sharpness of these leaves something to be desired. I have nicked myself a very few times after using them for over a year. It often takes multiple goings-overs to get a completely clean shave. Other commenter have mentioned the glue that sticks to each blade. This is by far the biggest downside to the product. The glue, if not properly removed (which is a pain) will accumulate hair just underneath the razor itself. I am able to use about 1 razor a week, which is just fine. A great deal, but with the sacrifice of cost comes a sacrifice of quality in this case.
  1921. I bought these since they were only $10. Lets just say I'm trying find ways to get rid of them. They are usually good for about 1-2 shaves before the blades go dull. Even brand new, they aren't as sharp as the Derby or Feather razors. After using this product I realized how great Feather blades were. If I have light stubble, this blade will do the work. If I want to have the best shave, Feather wins hands down.
  1922. They are very sharp. I use them 3-4 times before tossing them
  1923. You cannot beat Astra, the best blades for the price, you can pay the extra 10 or 11 dollars and get 100 feathers which are also great blades, but I don't know why you would, because I really don't see any difference.
  1924. I'm a big fan of the Astra Platinums. I've been double edge shaving for about a year. For the first 3 months I used various razors from a large assortment that a friend had given me who had also given me the razor. I tried the wide variety of blades and out of the selection he gave me I decided between this blade and another as my favorites. The astras gave me a great balance of longevity, close shave, and no razor burn. The other blade I liked was quite a bit more than this one so I bought this one instead. For me and my old '56 Gillet handle I can't beat the Astra Platinums.
  1925. Great blades excellent price.
  1926. I love the shave that I get with these razors
  1927. Not as sharp or long lasting as Feather, but also not as expensive. No irritations.
  1928. These are some smooth shaving blades! I was a little skeptical at first given the price, but they have certainly proven to be a great value. I've tried Derby's, but they cut too roughly. I've also used feather's which shaved well, but were quite a bit more expensive than these.
  1929. I've been using these blades almost exclusively for over a year. They are a good balance of sharp and durable. Even though the blade is still OK after 3 shaves, I like to change it out. $16 for a year of fresh daily shaving is great!
  1930. Cheap and sharp, what more do you want.. I get three shaves out of a blade and on to a new one..I shave every day and some times twice a day..<br />My 5 O'clock shadow comes in at about noon.. Tried a sample pack from the cheapest to the most expensive, these are great.. About a dime a piece..
  1931. For the price these things are great. I've been through 3 of the 5 packs now (15 blades for those bad at math), and while they are sharp and perform as they should, they just aren't sharp enough for me. 2 of those 15 blades started to pull on their first pass. I'd suggest buying a variety pack to try some other blades, feather hasn't pulled yet for me, so I'll be switching to those even with the considerable price premium. I'd rather spend the extra money for less skin irritation. I'm not rating this 5 stars because some of the razors are perfect, just a couple weren't.
  1932. Fantastic blades and a fantastic price! For anyone that is thinking about switching to a safety razor the price of blades alone should be enough to convince you. Prior to switching I would spend spend $200+ a year on blades and for $10 i just got high quality blades that will last me for 2 years.
  1933. first time using these bad boys and so far working great !!! saving me huge amount of money from not having to buy Gillette throw away razors. I have very hard hair on my face and these blades cut right through. They last a lot longer than lets say store bought plastic razors,even the expensive ones. stay sharp my freind
  1934. Finally found a blade for me. I recommend testing a lot of blades amazing to think they will react differently to your face but they do. I have very sensitive skin and went to a DE because conventional razors make absolutely no sense....5 blades = more friction with more surface area...simple science. These blades are great they shave amd sahve smooth for my skin and again I am a 10 on the sensitive scale some other blades like shark persona have left my face in sad shape. I also recommend Taylor of Bond Street Cream and Prorazo aftershave perfect combo and shaving is now enjoyable.

  1938. These are the best double-edge blades I've used yet, and for the price, I see no reason to buy anything else.
  1939. these are so sharp and exactly what I wanted. My hairdresser always uses double sided razors to shape my eye brows and since Im away at school I got these to do my upkeep. Its a little tricky doing it on my own, especially since these are so sharp..but they do a good job
  1940. This was my second sample pack, I initially worked through a 100 pack of derby blades which are also very smooth, but not as good for me as the Astra.
  1941. Great blades, great price.
  1942. Recent convgs to safety razors. Ended replacements, and these were an excellent buy. Not only are they a great price, but VERY sharp and get the job done!
  1943. These blades are really sharp out of the package so I use a cork to run the blade over one time to take the edge off of it. For the price you can't go wrong with them.
  1944. My husband likes to use the feather blades he says that they cannot be beat, but the price of these blades is amazing so we had to just try them out. My husbands facial hair is very coarse and these did an average job, but the difference in smoothness compared to his feather blades is huge. These blades last him about 2 shaves whereas his feather blades last him at least a week. These blades also come wrapped in wax paper and unless you have some sort of blade disposal canister these blades in the trash can be dangerous. He used these blades for about a month before we just ordered him some more Feather blades. These blades might work for you if you have fine soft facial hair, but if it is thick and coarse they aren't worth it.
  1945. Reviews on shaving forum were a bit mixed, but tended to weigh in on the positive side. So far, on blade #2, I've only had one decent shave. The rest have all ended with multiple weepers. I'll try a few more, but looks like I wasted my money here. I'll have to go back to my Israel Personna or Derby blades.
  1946. I've been trying out different safety razor blades for the past two years, and in the end every single one failed one critical test; my mustache. No matter what, it always felt like the blades were tugging and ripping out the hair, rather than gently gliding and cutting. On the recommendation of a friend, I gave Astra a shot. I didn't even feel the blade gliding across my upper lip as the hair was painlessly and effortlessly cut away.<br /><br />Astra has my business for the rest of my life. That's the highest praise I could give.
  1947. I use these primarily in my excellent Standard Razors Black, and no other razor/blade combo of the many I have tried gives such a close, comfortable, and effective shave. Normally, I only attempt to get two shaves from these blades, since the third shave isn't quite as good, but with the low price of these blades, the price per excellent shave is still among the lowest you will find anywhere. Highly recommended!
  1948. I love these blades. Close shave, long lasting and good quality! I imagine it will be a while before I have to buy new blades, but when I do, I'll buy these again!
  1949. About average blades in cut. Somes other brands cut better, some others not as close as Astra. But I do have to shave daily and these Astra blades are less aggressive compared to some. On Sunday's or special occasions I use a different brand. However, these are good for me on a day-to-day bases just going to work.
  1950. For the price and quantity these blades can't be beat. I just started DE shaving and have found these blades to be excellent. They give a nice, close shave. Obviously, you need to find what works for you; but I love these.
  1951. These blades are sharp and you absolutely cannot argue with the price on them. 2 years of shaving for the price of 2 months? Count me in.
  1952. I normally don't like to write bad reviews on products but after only using this for a second time shaving, I will not be using this product if I don't need to. I have been using blades to shave now for over 2 years and never experienced blades that were this dull....i tried with the first blade and it just felt like it was dull and didn't give me a clean shave....I am used to getting at least 2 good shaves of a single blade...but i decided, to try with a brand new blade for my second shave to see if it was just that single blade....similar experience...I wouldn't purchase this large count until trying the blades out for yourself...i am not saying you won't be able to shave with these BUT I just am not a fan of the sharpness of these blades personally and I will be looking for a different product ASAP.
  1953. Great value in terms of quality of blades as well as price.
  1954. This is a product you can't pass up. Well made and they stay sharp for a long time. I highly recommend these blades!!!
  1955. These blades are my favorite of the few companies I have tried. I don't have any razor bumps or cuts from these, which I almost always get.
  1956. Super Sharp & Clean, Keeps the edge well
  1957. There is nothing wrong with these blades. They work the way they are suppose to. The shave is close, and comfortable

  1959. These blades are very good quality and shave like a dream. I have tried a variety of double edge razor blades, but these are hands down the best! No tugging and pulling on hairs, just a smooth shaving experience. These blades work flawlessly and come at a price that make it a no brainer. Lose the multiblade razors and start shaving a like a man with these little katanas!
  1960. After trying a sample pack I find these the best balance of sharpness and durability. Everyone worships Feather's but they are the only blades that consistently give me razor burn/irritation. No complaints at all with Astra's and they are a great value as well!
  1961. These blades are a great value and deliver a great shave. I have tried multiple brands and though these aren't the best I have used they work very well when shaving my head.
  1962. These are very high quality Double Edge shaving blades at a GREAT price. When I started shaving with double edged razors, I tried a range of different products and found the Astra Superior Platinum to be the best for my beard and budget. I tried a few others that were much more expensive that were very good (Feathers) but almost *too* sharp, yet deteriorated quickly. There were others that were cheaper that I liked but did not retain a sharp blade as long as the Astras. Of course, if you are just starting your experimentation, you might find that the Astras do not meet your needs. You should buy a range of blades and experiment for a couple months.<br /><br />Once I determined I liked the Astras, I was thrilled to find the 100 pack for about 10 to 12 bucks. I get two weeks out of a blade (see below) so this supply will last me roughly two years. I'd spend the same money on Gillette or Schick cartridge blades in under a month.<br /><br />PLEASE NOTE - you can use BOTH SIDES of a double edge razor blade, and one of the benefits of these Astras is that they have four small numerals in the corners of the blade referring to each edge (1 and 2 on one side, 3 and 4 on the other side). More info at http://wiki.badgerandblade.com/Numbers_on_the_DE_Blade<br /><br />Why is this beneficial? Because I get a week out of each side of the blade. I don't pay attention to whether I use the 1 edge or the 2 edge, but I get a solid week out of the \\"top\\" of the blade (which I count as 1 and 2 facing me when loading the razor), then after shaving on Sunday, I flip it over so the 3 and 4 is facing me and get another solid week out of it. If you think about it, only one side of the blade (facing down when the handle is facing down) is ever doing the cutting. So the numerals help me remember whether it is a week for me to \\"flip\\" the blade or \\"discard\\" the blade. I probably could push the one week duration for each side even longer, but I'm happy with getting two solid weeks out ofit and never cut myself.<br /><br />BTW, in response to someone's question, I keep spent blades in a large pill bottle (childproof cap) from the pharmacy, works great, and it will take forever for me to fill it. I have no kids in my household.
  1963. Absolutely the best shave I have ever had. I switched to a safety razor a while back and won't ever go back to electric or disposable blades again. These are so much cheaper than what you would normally pay for with alternatives. At 10 cents a blade, I use a new blade every time I shave and it is still a fraction of the price of something like a Mach 3 razor at $2 per blade.
  1964. I placed an order for a box of 100 blades alongside the Merkur long handle safety razor. The cut of the blades and overall comfort are matched by no other brand for this price. I will continue to purchase Astra Platinum blades from now on.
  1965. Nice sharp blades, they will get the job done and better than some cheaper blades out there, no complaints. keep on shavin!
